title: On the Fairness of Additive Welfarist Rules

sections.text:
## ABSTRACT

Allocating indivisible goods is a ubiquitous task in fair division. We study additive welfarist rules, an important class of rules which choose an allocation that maximizes the sum of some function of the agents' utilities. Prior work has shown that the maximum Nash welfare (MNW) rule is the unique additive welfarist rule that guarantees envy-freeness up to one good (EF1). We strengthen this result by showing that MNW remains the only additive welfarist rule that ensures EF1 for identical-good instances, two-value instances, as well as normalized instances with three or more agents. On the other hand, if the agents' utilities are integers, we demonstrate that several other rules offer the EF1 guarantee, and provide characterizations of these rules for various classes of instances.

## KEYWORDS

Welfarist rules; Fair division; Indivisible goods

## 1 INTRODUCTION

The distribution of limited resources to interested agents is a fundamental problem in society. Fairness often plays a key role in the distribution process-whether it be dividing inheritance between family members, allocating the national budget across competing sectors, or sharing credit and responsibility amongst participants in collaborative efforts. The complexity of this problem has led to the research area of fair division, which develops methods and algorithms to ensure that all agents feel fairly treated [4, 18, 19].

What does it mean for an allocation of the resources to be "fair"? The answer depends on the context and the specific fairness benchmark applied. One of the most prominent fairness criteria is envyfreeness, which states that no agent should prefer another agent's share to her own. In the ubiquitous setting of allocating indivisible goods-such as houses, cars, jewelry, and artwork-it is sometimes infeasible to attain envy-freeness. For example, if a single valuable good is to be allocated between two or more agents, only one of the agents can receive the good, thereby incurring envy from the remaining agents. In light of this, envy-freeness is often relaxed to envy-freeness up to one good (EF1). The EF1 criterion allows an agent to envy another agent provided that the removal of some good in the latter agent's bundle would eliminate the former agent's envy. It is known that an EF1 allocation always exists, and that such an allocation can be computed in polynomial time [5, 15].

In addition to fairness, another important property of allocations is efficiency. A well-known efficiency notion is Pareto optimality (PO), which stipulates that no other allocation makes some agent better off and no agent worse off. Caragiannis et al. [6] proved that a maximum Nash welfare (MNW) allocation, which maximizes the product of the agents' utilities across all possible allocations, ${ }^{1}$ satisfies both EF1 and PO, thereby offering fairness and efficiency

[^0]simultaneously. In spite of this, the MNW rule does have limitations. For example, it avoids giving an agent zero utility at all costban allocation that gives most agents a tiny positive utility is preferred to another allocation that gives one agent zero utility and every other agent a large utility, as illustrated in the following example.

Example 1.1. Consider an instance with $n \geq 4$ agents and $n$ goods $g_{1}, \ldots, g_{n}$ such that the utilities of the goods are as follows.

- $u_{1}\left(g_{1}\right)=n$.
- For $i \in\{2, \ldots, n\}, u_{i}\left(g_{i-1}\right)=n-1$ and $u_{i}\left(g_{i}\right)=1$.
- $u_{i}(g)=0$ for all other pairs $(i, g)$.

The only allocation $\mathcal{A}$ that gives positive utility to every agent is the one that assigns good $g_{i}$ to agent $i$ for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, n\}$-this is also the MNW allocation. The sum of the agents' utilities in this allocation is $n+(n-1)=2 n-1$. On the other hand, consider the allocation $\mathcal{B}$ that gives good $g_{1}$ to agent $1, g_{i}$ to agent $i+1$ for $i \in\{2, \ldots, n-1\}$, and $g_{n}$ to agent $n$. The sum of the agents' utilities in this allocation is $n^{2}-2 n+3$, which is much larger than that in $\mathcal{A}$. Not only is $\mathcal{B}$ also EF1 and PO, but one agent receives the same utility, all remaining agents except one receive much higher utility, while the exceptional agent receives only marginally lower utility.

The MNW rule belongs to the class of additive welfarist rulesrules that choose an allocation that maximizes the sum of some function of the agents' utilities for their bundles [18, p. 67]. Additive welfarist rules have the advantage that they satisfy PO by definition. Suksompong [20] showed that MNW is the only additive welfarist rule ${ }^{2}$ that guarantees EF1 for all instances. Nevertheless, there exist other additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for restricted classes of instances. For example, Montanari et al. [17, Appendix C] proved that the maximum harmonic welfare (MHW) rule ensures EF1 for the class of integer-valued instances. Note that this is an important class of instances in practice-for example, the popular fair division website Spliddit [11] only allows each user to specify integer values for goods summing up to 1000. In Example 1.1, allocation $\mathcal{B}$ is the MHW allocation, and we saw earlier that $\mathcal{B}$ has certain advantages compared to the MNW allocation $\mathcal{A}$. Beyond integer-valued instances, Eckart et al. [9] showed that certain additive welfarist rules based on $p$-mean functions, besides the MNW rule, also yield EF1 for the class of normalized instances with two agents-normalized instances have the property that the utility for the entire set of goods is the same for every agent.

In this paper, we study the necessary and sufficient conditions for additive welfarist rules to guarantee EF1 for different classes of instances. These classes include integer-valued instances, identicalgood instances, two-value instances, normalized instances, as well as some of their combinations. We also establish relationships between the conditions for different classes of instances.

sections.text:
### 1.1 Our Results

In our model, we assume that each agent has an additive utility function over a set of indivisible goods. We consider additive welfarist rules, each of which is defined by a function $f$; the rule chooses an allocation that maximizes the sum of the function $f$ applied to the agents' utilities for their own bundles. In order for the additive welfarist rules to ensure that agents receive as much utility as possible, we assume that $f$ is strictly increasing. ${ }^{3}$ For our characterizations, we only consider instances that are positive-admitting, i.e., instances where there exists an allocation that gives positive utility to every agent. ${ }^{4}$ Our model is described formally in Section 2.

We then examine conditions for an additive welfarist rule to always choose EF1 allocations, starting with general (real-valued) instances. As mentioned earlier, the MNW rule is the unique additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1 for all (positive-admitting) instances [20]. In Section 3, we strengthen this result by showing that, for identical-good instances as well as for two-value instances, MNW remains the unique additive welfarist rule that ensures EF1. Furthermore, we prove that the same holds for normalized instances with three or more agents-this extends a result of Eckart et al. [9, Thm. 6], which only handles additive welfarist rules defined by $p$-mean functions. For normalized instances with two agents, however, this characterization ceases to hold, and we provide a necessary condition and a sufficient condition for additive welfarist rules to guarantee EF1.

In Section 4, we consider integer-valued instances. For such instances, not only the MNW rule but also the MHW rule guarantees EF1 [17]. We shall attempt to characterize rules with this property. We show that for identical-good, binary, and two-value instances (which are also integer-valued), the respective functions defining the additive welfarist rules are characterized by Conditions 3, 4,

[^0]and 5 respectively (see Definition 2.1). This allows much larger classes of functions beyond the MNW rule or the MHW rule. We provide examples and non-examples of modified logarithmic functions and modified harmonic functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 in these classes of instances. For the larger class of all integer-valued instances, we give a necessary condition and a sufficient condition for such additive welfarist rules.

For all of our characterization results (Theorems 3.1, 3.14, 3.15, $4.1,4.7$, and 4.11 ), we show that if a function defining an additive welfarist rule guarantees EF1 for that particular class of instance for some number of agents $n$, then it also guarantees EF1 for that class for every number of agents $n$.

Our results are summarized in Table 1. The relationships between the different conditions are summarized in Figure 1, and the relationships between additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for different classes of instances are illustrated in Figure 2.

## 2 PRELIMINARIES

Let $N=\{1, \ldots, n\}$ be a set of $n \geq 2$ agents and $M=\left\{g_{1}, \ldots, g_{m}\right\}$ be a set of goods. Each agent $i \in N$ has a utility function $u_{i}: 2^{M} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ such that $u_{i}(S)$ is $i$ 's utility for a subset $S$ of goods; we write $u_{i}(g)$ instead of $u_{i}(\{g\})$ for a single good $g \in M$. The utility function is additive, i.e., for each $S \subseteq M, u_{i}(S)=\sum_{g \in S} u_{i}(g)$. An instance consists of $N, M_{i}$ and $\left(u_{i}\right)_{i \in N}$.

An allocation $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ is an ordered partition of $M$ into $n$ bundles $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}$ such that $A_{i}$ is allocated to agent $i \in N$. An allocation is envy-free up to one good (EF1) if for all $i, j \in N$ with $A_{j} \neq \varnothing$, there exists a good $g \in A_{j}$ such that $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \geq u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\{g\}\right)$.

We say that an instance is

- integer-valued if $u_{i}(g) \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ for all $i \in N$ and $g \in M$;
- identical-good if for each $i \in N$, there exists $a_{i} \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that $u_{i}(g)=a_{i}$ for all $g \in M$;
- binary if $u_{i}(g) \in\{0,1\}$ for all $i \in N$ and $g \in M$;
- two-value if there exist distinct $a_{1}, a_{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ such that $u_{i}(g) \in\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}\right\}$ for all $i \in N$ and $g \in M ;{ }^{5}$

[^1]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ If $f$ is not strictly increasing, then the allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule may not even be PO. In fact, we show in Appendix B that even if $f$ is non-decreasing but not strictly increasing, then there exists an identical-good normalized instance such that the additive welfarist rule with function $f$ does not always choose an EF1 allocation. This means that it is desirable for $f$ to be strictly increasing.
    ${ }^{4}$ Even the MNW rule does not always return EF1 for instances that are not positiveadmitting, unless there are additional tie-breaking mechanisms [6].

[^1]:    ${ }^{5}$ Two-value instances have received attention in fair division, particularly in relation to the MNW rule [1, 2].

- normalized if $u_{i}(M)=u_{j}(M)$ for all $i, j \in N$;
- positive-admitting if there exists an allocation $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ such that $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)>0$ for all $i \in N$.

Let an instance be given. An additive welfarist rule is defined by a strictly increasing function $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ such that the rule chooses an allocation $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ that maximizes $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$; if there are multiple such allocations, the rule chooses one arbitrarily. Since $f$ is strictly increasing, $f(x)=-\infty$ implies that $x=0$, which means that $f(x) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$.

A function $f$ is strictly concave if for any distinct $x, y \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ and $\alpha \in(0,1)$, we have $f(\alpha x+(1-\alpha) y)>\alpha f(x)+(1-\alpha) f(y)$. We use $\log$ to denote the natural logarithm, and define $\log 0$ as $-\infty$.

Definition 2.1. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. For each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$, define $\Delta_{f, k}: \mathbb{R}_{>0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{\infty\}$ such that $\Delta_{f, k}(x)=f((k+1) x)-f(k x)$. The function $f$ is said to satisfy

- Condition 1 if $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$
- Condition 1a if $\Delta_{f, k}$ is a constant function (on domain $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ ) for every $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$
- Condition 2 if $f(a)+f(b)<f(c)+f(d)$ for all $a, b, c, d \in$ $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ such that $\min \{a, b\} \leq \min \{c, d\}$ and $a b<c d$;
- Condition 3 if $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$
- Condition 3a if $\Delta_{f, \ell}(b)>\Delta_{f, k}(a)$ for all $k, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $\ell<k$;
- Condition 3b if $\Delta_{f, k}(1)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)>\Delta_{f, k+2}(1)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$
- Condition 4 if $\Delta_{f, k}(1)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(1)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$
- Condition 5 if $f((\ell+1) b+r a)-f(t b+r a)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)>$ $\Delta_{f, k+2}(1)$ for all $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $k, \ell, r \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $a \geq b$ and $(k+1) b>t b+r a$
- Condition 6a if $f((k+1) b-1)-f(k b-1)>\Delta_{f, k}(a)$ for all $k, a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$
- Condition 6b if $f(y+b)-f(y)>f(x+a)-f(x)$ for all $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $x / a \geq(y+1) / b$.

Note that for $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, we have $f((k+1) x)>f(k x)$ since $f$ is strictly increasing, so $\Delta_{f, k}$ is well-defined and positive. Moreover, we have $\Delta_{f, k}(x)=\infty$ if and only if $k=0$ and $f(0)=$ $-\infty$.

### 2.1 Examples of Additive Welfarist Rules

The maximum Nash welfare (MNW) rule is the additive welfarist rule defined by the function log. We consider variations of this rule by defining, for each $c \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, the modified logarithmic function $\lambda_{c}: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ such that $\lambda_{c}(x)=\log (x+c)$.

The maximum harmonic welfare (MHW) rule is the additive welfarist rule defined by the function $h_{0}(x)=\sum_{t=1}^{x} 1 / t$. Note that this definition only makes sense when $x$ is a non-negative integer; hence, we extend its definition to the non-negative real domain using the function $h_{0}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1-t^{x}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t$ [12]. We also consider variations of this rule. We define, for each $c \geq-1$, the modified harmonic

Each region, labeled by $F$ with a subscript, represents the set of functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for the class of instances corresponding to the subscript. Some examples of these functions are given in the respective regions.
number $h_{c}: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ such that ${ }^{6}$

$$
h_{-1}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1-t^{x-1}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \quad \text { and } \quad h_{c}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{x+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

for $c>-1$. When the domain of $h_{c}$ is restricted to the set of nonnegative integers, we can rewrite ${ }^{7}$ the values as

$$
h_{-1}(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\sum_{t=1}^{x-1} \frac{1}{t} & \text { if } x \geq 1 \\
-\infty & \text { if } x=0
\end{array} \quad\right. \text { and } \quad h_{c}(x)=\sum_{t=1}^{x} \frac{1}{t+c}
$$

for $c>-1$ and all $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$.
An MNW allocation (resp. MHW allocation) is an allocation chosen by the MNW rule (resp. MHW rule).

For $p \in \mathbb{R}$, the (generalized) $p$-mean rule is an additive welfarist rule defined by the function $\varphi_{p}$, where

$$
\varphi_{p}(x)= \begin{cases}x^{p} & \text { if } p>0 \\ \log x & \text { if } p=0 \\ -x^{p} & \text { if } p<0\end{cases}
$$

Hence, the MNW rule is also the 0 -mean rule.

## 3 REAL-VALUED INSTANCES

We start with the general case where the utility of a good can be any (non-negative) real number. As mentioned earlier, the only additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1 for all such instances is the MNW rule [20]. In this section, we consider the subclasses of identical-good instances (Section 3.1), two-value instances (Section 3.2), and normalized instances (Section 3.3). We demonstrate that the characterization of MNW continues to hold for the first two classes, as well as for the third class when there are three or more agents. To this end, we show that the only additive welfarist rule that ensures EF1 for these classes of instances is defined by

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ This family of functions is defined for $c \in[-1,0]$ in the domain of non-negative integers in previous work [17].
    ${ }^{7}$ We prove this equivalence in Appendix C.

the logarithmic function, which is equivalent to Conditions 1 and 1a.

### 3.1 Identical-Good Instances

Recall that identical-good instances have the property that each agent assigns the same utility to every good, although the utilities may be different for different agents. We state the characterization for such instances.

Theorem 3.1. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting identical-good instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.
(b) There exist constants $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\beta \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x)=$ $\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.
Note that the MNW rule is equivalent to the additive welfarist rule with a function that satisfies Theorem 3.1(b); therefore, the theorem essentially says that the only additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1 for identical-good instances is the MNW rule.

We shall prove the theorem via a series of lemmas. We begin by showing that Condition 1 is a necessary condition for a function $f$ that satisfies the statement in Theorem 3.1(a).

Lemma 3.2. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function such that the statement in Theorem 3.1(a) holds. Then, $f$ satisfies Condition 1.

Proof. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ be given. Consider an instance with $n$ agents and $(k+1) n$ goods such that the utility of each good is $a$ for agent 1 and $b$ for the remaining agents. This instance is an identical-good instance; moreover, it is positive-admitting since the allocation where every agent receives $k+1$ goods gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be the allocation such that every agent receives $k+1$ goods. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=f((k+1) a)+(n-$ 1) $f((k+1) b)$. Note that $\mathcal{A}$ is the only EF1 allocation; indeed, if some agent does not receive exactly $k+1$ goods, then some agent $i$ receives fewer than $k+1$ goods while another agent $j$ receives more than $k+1$ goods, so agent $i$ envies agent $j$ by at least two goods, thereby violating EF1. Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the allocation such that agent 1 receives $k+2$ goods, agent 2 receives $k$ goods, and every other agent receives $k+1$ goods. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)=$ $f((k+2) a)+f(k b)+(n-2) f((k+1) b)$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is the only EF1 allocation, the additive welfarist rule with $f$ chooses (only) $\mathcal{A}$, and it holds that $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)>\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get

$$
f((k+1) b)-f(k b)>f((k+2) a)-f((k+1) a)
$$

or equivalently, $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$. Since $k, a, b$ were arbitrarily chosen, $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$ holds for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Therefore, $f$ satisfies Condition 1.

Next, we show that Condition 1 is sufficient for the function $f$ to satisfy Theorem 3.1(b). To this end, we prove in Lemmas 3.3 and 3.8 that Condition 1 implies Condition 1a, which in turn implies that $f$ satisfies the statement in Theorem 3.1(b).

Lemma 3.3. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 1. Then, $f$ satisfies Condition 1a.

We shall prove Lemma 3.3 via a series of lemmas. Let $\inf \Delta_{f, k}=$ $\inf \left\{\Delta_{f, k}(x): x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}\right\}$ and $\sup \Delta_{f, k}=\sup \left\{\Delta_{f, k}(x): x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}\right\}$.

Lemma 3.4. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. Then, we have $\Delta_{f, k}(x)=$ $\Delta_{f, 2 k}(x / 2)+\Delta_{f, 2 k+1}(x / 2)$.

Proof. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{f, k}(x)= & f((k+1) x)-f(k x) \\
= & f\left((2 k+2) \frac{x}{2}\right)-f\left((2 k) \frac{x}{2}\right) \\
= & f\left((2 k+1) \frac{x}{2}\right)-f\left((2 k) \frac{x}{2}\right) \\
& +f\left((2 k+2) \frac{x}{2}\right)-f\left((2 k+1) \frac{x}{2}\right) \\
= & \Delta_{f, 2 k}\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)+\Delta_{f, 2 k+1}\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 3.5. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 1. Then, $\sup \Delta_{f, k}$ and $\inf \Delta_{f, k}$ are both non-negative and finite. Moreover, $\inf \Delta_{f, k} \geq$ $\sup \Delta_{f, k+1}$.

Proof. First, we show non-negativity. For $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, it holds that $(k+1) x>k x$. Since $f$ is strictly increasing, we have $f((k+$ 1) $x)>f(k x)$, which implies that $\Delta_{f, k}(x)>0$. Therefore, both $\inf \Delta_{f, k}$ and $\sup \Delta_{f, k}$ are non-negative.

Next, we show finiteness. Let $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. For $k \geq 2$, since $f$ satisfies Condition 1, we have $\Delta_{f, k}(x)<\Delta_{f, k-1}(1)<\cdots<\Delta_{f, 1}(1)=$ $f(2)-f(1)$, which is finite, so $\sup \Delta_{f, k}$ is finite. For $k=1$, we have $\Delta_{f, 1}(x)=\Delta_{f, 2}(x / 2)+\Delta_{f, 3}(x / 2)$ by Lemma 3.4, and the latter is upper-bounded by $\sup \Delta_{f, 2}+\sup \Delta_{f, 3}$, which is finite, so $\sup \Delta_{f, 1}$ is also finite. Therefore, $\sup \Delta_{f, k}$ is finite for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Since $\inf \Delta_{f, k} \leq \sup \Delta_{f, k}$, the finiteness of $\inf \Delta_{f, k}$ follows.

Finally, since $f$ satisfies Condition 1, we get $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$ for all $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. This implies that $\inf \Delta_{f, k} \geq \sup \Delta_{f, k+1}$.

For $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, define $d_{f, k}=\sup \Delta_{f, k}-\inf \Delta_{f, k}$. Note that $d_{f, k}$ is well-defined and finite by Lemma 3.5.

Lemma 3.6. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 1. Then, $0 \leq$ $d_{f, k} \leq d_{f, 2 k}+d_{f, 2 k+1}$.

Proof. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and note that $d_{f, k} \geq 0$ holds trivially. By the definitions of supremum and infimum, there exist sequences of positive real numbers $\left(a_{t}\right)_{t \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}}$ and $\left(b_{t}\right)_{t \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}}$ such that

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{f, k}\left(a_{t}\right)=\sup \Delta_{f, k} \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{f, k}\left(b_{t}\right)=\inf \Delta_{f, k}
$$

Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{f, k} & =\sup \Delta_{f, k}-\inf \Delta_{f, k} \\
& =\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{f, k}\left(a_{t}\right)-\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{f, k}\left(b_{t}\right) \\
& =\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\left(\Delta_{f, k}\left(a_{t}\right)-\Delta_{f, k}\left(b_{t}\right)\right) \\
& =\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\left(\Delta_{f, 2 k}\left(\frac{a_{t}}{2}\right)+\Delta_{f, 2 k+1}\left(\frac{a_{t}}{2}\right)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\Delta_{f, 2 k}\left(\frac{b_{t}}{2}\right)-\Delta_{f, 2 k+1}\left(\frac{b_{t}}{2}\right) \quad \quad \text { (by Lemma 3.4) } \\
\leq & \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sup \Delta_{f, 2 k}+\sup \Delta_{f, 2 k+1}-\inf \Delta_{f, 2 k}-\inf \Delta_{f, 2 k+1}\right) \\
& \quad \text { (since each term is finite by Lemma 3.5) } \\
= & \sup \Delta_{f, 2 k}-\inf \Delta_{f, 2 k}+\sup \Delta_{f, 2 k+1}-\inf \Delta_{f, 2 k+1} \\
= & d_{f, 2 k}+d_{f, 2 k+1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 3.7. Let $r \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 1. Then,

$$
\ell \cdot \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \leq \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}
$$

Proof. We prove this statement by induction on $\ell$. The base case $\ell=1$ holds trivially. For the inductive step, assume that

$$
\ell \cdot \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \leq \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}
$$

holds for some $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$; we shall prove the statement for $\ell+1$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\ell+1) \cdot \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} & \leq \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}+\sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \\
& \text { (by the inductive hypothesis) } \\
& \leq \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}+\sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1}\left(d_{f, 2 t}+d_{f, 2 t+1}\right) \\
& \text { (by Lemma 3.6) } \\
& =\sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}+\sum_{t=2^{r+1}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \\
& =\sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}
\end{aligned}
$$

completing the induction.
We are now ready to prove Lemma 3.3.
Proof of Lemma 3.3. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be given. It suffices to show that $d_{f, k}=0$. Note that $d_{f, k}$ is non-negative by Lemma 3.6.

Let $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Define $r=\left\lfloor\log _{2} k\right\rfloor$ and $s=k-2^{r}$, so that $k=2^{r}+s$ for $r, s \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ with $s<2^{r}$. Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ell d_{f, k} \leq \ell\left(d_{f, 2^{r}}+\cdots+d_{f, k}+\cdots+d_{f, 2^{r}+\left(2^{r}-1\right)}\right) \\
& \text { (since } d_{f, t} \geq 0 \text { by Lemma 3.6) } \\
= & \ell \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \\
\leq & \sum_{t=2^{\ell}}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \\
\leq & \sum_{t=1}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t}
\end{aligned}
$$

(by Lemma 3.7)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq \sum_{t=1}^{2^{r+1}-1} d_{f, t} \quad \text { (since } d_{f, t} \geq 0 \text { by Lemma 3.6) } \\
& =\sum_{t=1}^{2^{r+1}-1}\left(\sup \Delta_{f, t}-\inf \Delta_{f, t}\right) \quad \text { (by definition) } \\
& \leq \sum_{t=1}^{2^{r+1}-1}\left(\sup \Delta_{f, t}-\sup \Delta_{f, t+1}\right) \quad \text { (by Lemma 3.5) } \\
& =\sup \Delta_{f, 1}-\sup \Delta_{f, 2^{r+\ell}} \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \leq \sup \Delta_{f, 1} . \quad \text { (since } \sup \Delta_{f, 2^{r+\ell}} \geq 0 \text { by Lemma 3.5) }
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives $0 \leq d_{f, k} \leq\left(\sup \Delta_{f, 1}\right) / \ell$. Since $\ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ is arbitrary and $\sup \Delta_{f, 1}$ is a finite non-negative constant by Lemma 3.5, we conclude that $d_{f, k}=0$.

Next, we state another key lemma.
Lemma 3.8. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, there exist constants $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\beta \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x)=\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.

We remark that Suksompong [20, Lemma 2] proved a result similar to Lemma 3.8 but made the stronger assumption that the function $f$ is differentiable. Our result only assumes continuity. Again, we establish Lemma 3.8 via a series of intermediate results. For each $t \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, define $q_{f, t}: \mathbb{R}_{>0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $q_{f, t}(x)=f(t x)-$ $f(x)$.

Lemma 3.9. Let $t>1$ be a rational number, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function.

Proof. Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, and let $t=a / b$ with $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Since $t>1$, we have $a>b$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{f, t}(x) & =f(t x)-f(x) \\
& =\sum_{k=b}^{q-1} f\left(\frac{k+1}{b} x\right)-f\left(\frac{k}{b} x\right) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =\sum_{k=b}^{q-1} \Delta_{f, k}(x / b) \\
& =\sum_{k=b}^{q-1} \Delta_{f, k}(y / b) \quad \text { (since } \Delta_{f, k} \text { is constant) } \\
& =\sum_{k=b}^{q-1} f\left(\frac{k+1}{b} y\right)-f\left(\frac{k}{b} y\right) \\
& =f(t y)-f(y) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =q_{f, t}(y) .
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function.
Lemma 3.10. Let $t>1$ be an irrational number, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function.

Proof. Let $x, y \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, and let $\epsilon>0$. Since $f$ is continuous at $t x$ and $t y$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that for all $x^{\prime} \in(t x-\delta, t x+\delta)$ we have $\left|f(t x)-f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right|<\epsilon / 2$, and for all $y^{\prime} \in(t y-\delta, t y+\delta)$ we have $\left|f(t y)-f\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right|<\epsilon / 2$. Moreover, there exists a rational number $t^{\prime}$ such that $t<t^{\prime}<t+\min \{\delta / x, \delta / y\}$. Then, we have $t^{\prime} x \in(t x-$

$\delta, t x+\delta)$ and $t^{\prime} y \in(t y-\delta, t y+\delta)$, and hence $\left|f(t x)-f\left(t^{\prime} x\right)\right|<\epsilon / 2$ and $\left|f(t y)-f\left(t^{\prime} y\right)\right|<\epsilon / 2$. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|q_{f, t}(x)-q_{f, t}(y)\right|= & \mid(f(t x)-f(x))-\left(f(t y)-f(y)\right) \mid \\
= & \mid\left(f(t x)-f\left(t^{\prime} x\right)+f\left(t^{\prime} x\right)-f(x)\right) \\
& -\left(f(t y)-f\left(t^{\prime} y\right)+f\left(t^{\prime} y\right)-f(y)\right) \mid \\
\leq & \mid\left(f\left(t^{\prime} x\right)-f(x)\right)-\left(f\left(t^{\prime} y\right)-f(y)\right) \mid \\
& +\left|f(t x)-f\left(t^{\prime} x\right)\right|+\left|f(t y)-f\left(t^{\prime} y\right)\right| \\
& \text { (by triangle inequality) } \\
< & \left|q_{f, t^{\prime}}(x)-q_{f, t^{\prime}}(y)\right|+\epsilon / 2+\epsilon / 2 \\
= & 0+\epsilon \\
= & \epsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\epsilon>0$ is arbitrary, we have $q_{f, t}(x)=q_{f, t}(y)$. It follows that $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function.

Lemma 3.11. Let $t$ be a positive real number, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function.

Proof. For $t>1$, this follows directly from Lemmas 3.9 and 3.10. For $t=1$, this is trivial. Finally, for $0<t<1$, this follows from the fact that $q_{f, 1 / t}$ is constant.

Define $q_{f}: \mathbb{R}_{>0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $q_{f}(t)=q_{f, t}(1)$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Since $q_{f, t}$ is a constant function for each $t \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ by Lemma 3.11, we have $q_{f}(t)=f(t)-f(1)=f(t x)-f(x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$.

Lemma 3.12. Let $b$ be a positive integer, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, $q_{f}\left(2^{1 / b}\right)=\frac{1}{b} q_{f}(2)$.

Proof. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{f}(2) & =f(2)-f(1) \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{b-1} f\left(2^{(k+1) / b}\right)-f\left(2^{k / b}\right) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{b-1} f\left(2^{1 / b} \cdot 2^{k / b}\right)-f\left(1 \cdot 2^{k / b}\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{b-1} q_{f}\left(2^{1 / b}\right) \\
& =b \cdot q_{f}\left(2^{1 / b}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies the desired result.
Lemma 3.13. Let $t$ be a rational number, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ that satisfies Condition 1a. Then, $q_{f}\left(2^{t}\right)=t q_{f}(2)$.

Proof. The result is trivial for $t=0$, since $q_{f}\left(2^{0}\right)=q_{f}(1)=$ $f(1)-f(1)=0$.

We first prove the result for positive $t$. Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $t=a / b$. Then, we have

$$
q_{f}\left(2^{a / b}\right)=f\left(2^{a / b}\right)-f(1)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{k=0}^{a-1} f\left(2^{(k+1) / b}\right)-f\left(2^{k / b}\right) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{a-1} f\left(2^{1 / b} \cdot 2^{k / b}\right)-f\left(1 \cdot 2^{k / b}\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=0}^{a-1} q_{f}\left(2^{1 / b}\right) \\
& =a \cdot q_{f}\left(2^{1 / b}\right) \\
& =\frac{a}{b} q_{f}(2) \\
& =t q_{f}(2)
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired.
Finally, we prove the result for negative $t$. Let $a$ be a negative integer and $b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $t=a / b$. Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{f}\left(2^{a / b}\right) & =f\left(2^{a / b} \cdot 2^{-a / b}\right)-f\left(1 \cdot 2^{-a / b}\right) \\
& =-\left(f\left(2^{-a / b}\right)-f(1)\right) \\
& =-q_{f}\left(2^{-a / b}\right) \\
& =-\left(-\frac{a}{b} q_{f}(2)\right) \quad \text { (by the first part of this proof) } \\
& =t q_{f}(2)
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired. Hence, $q_{f}\left(2^{t}\right)=t q_{f}(2)$ for all rational $t$.
We are now ready to prove Lemma 3.8.

Proof of Lemma 3.8. Let $\alpha=(f(2)-f(1)) / \log 2 \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\beta=f(1) \in \mathbb{R}$, and define $f_{0}: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ such that $f_{0}(x)=$ $\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.

We show that $f(x)=f_{0}(x)$ for all $x=2^{t}$ where $t$ is rational. Let $t$ be a rational number. By Lemma 3.13, $q_{f}\left(2^{t}\right)=t q_{f}(2)$, which implies that $f\left(2^{t}\right)-f(1)=t(f(2)-f(1))$. Since $f(1)=\beta$ and $f(2)-f(1)=\alpha \log 2$, we have $f\left(2^{t}\right)=t \alpha \log 2+\beta=\alpha \log \left(2^{t}\right)+\beta=$ $f_{0}\left(2^{t}\right)$, so $f(x)=f_{0}(x)$ for all $x=2^{t}$ where $t$ is rational.

Now, since $f$ and $f_{0}$ are continuous functions that coincide on the set $\left\{2^{t}: t\right.$ is rational $\}$, which is dense in $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$, we must have $f(x)=f_{0}(x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. For the case $x=0$, since $f$ is strictly increasing, we must have $f(0)<f(x)=\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. The only possibility for $f(0)$ is $f(0)=-\infty=f_{0}(0)$. This completes the proof that $f(x)=f_{0}(x)=\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.

Finally, we are ready to prove Theorem 3.1.

Proof of Theorem 3.1. The implication (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b) follows from Lemmas 3.2, 3.3, and 3.8, while the implication (b) $\Rightarrow$ (a) follows from the result of Caragiannis et al. [6].

Theorem 3.1 and Lemmas 3.2, 3.3, and 3.8 imply that a continuous function having the logarithmic property is equivalent to the function satisfying Conditions 1 and 1a (separately). We view this as an interesting mathematical property in itself.

### 3.2 Two-Value Instances

We now consider two-value instances, which are instances with only two possible utilities for the goods. Note that the classes of identical-good instances and two-value instances do not contain each other. Indeed, an identical-good instance with $n \geq 3$ agents may be $n$-value rather than two-value since each of the $n$ agents could assign a unique utility to the goods, ${ }^{8}$ whereas a two-value instance allows an agent to have varying utilities for different goods.

Despite this incomparability, we show that the same characterization for identical-good instances also holds for two-value instances.

Theorem 3.14. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup$ $\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting two-value instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.
(b) There exist constants $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\beta \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x)=$ $\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.

Proof. (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b): We claim that $f$ satisfies Condition 1. The proof of this claim is identical to that of Lemma 3.2, since the construction in the proof of Lemma 3.2 uses an instance that is also two-value. Then, by Lemmas 3.3 and 3.8, statement (b) holds.
(b) $\Rightarrow$ (a) follows from the result of Caragiannis et al. [6].

### 3.3 Normalized Instances

Next, we consider normalized instances, where agents assign the same utility to the entire set of goods $M$. We first consider the case of three or more agents. We show that just like for the cases of identical-good instances and two-value instances, the only additive welfarist rule that yields EF1 for this case is the MNW rule. This extends Theorem 6 of Eckart et al. [9], which only handles $p$-mean rules (as opposed to all additive welfarist rules).

Theorem 3.15. Let $n \geq 3$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup$ $\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting normalized instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.
(b) There exist constants $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\beta \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x)=$ $\alpha \log x+\beta$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$.

To prove Theorem 3.15, we cannot use the construction in the proof of Lemma 3.2 since the instance in that construction is not necessarily normalized. Instead, we show that the function defining the additive welfarist rule must satisfy Condition 1a. To this end, we augment the construction of Suksompong [20] by adding a highly valuable good and an extra agent who only values that good, so that the instance becomes normalized.

Lemma 3.16. Let $n \geq 3$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that the statement in Theorem 3.15(a) holds. Then, $f$ satisfies Condition 1a.

$$
f((k+1) a)-f(k a)>f((k+1) b-\epsilon)-f(k b-\epsilon)
$$

Consider an instance with $n$ agents and $m=k(n-1)+2$ goods. For ease of notation, let $c=\max \{k n a, k n b\}, N^{\prime}=N \backslash\{1, n\}, g^{\prime}=g_{m-1}$, $g^{\prime \prime}=g_{m}$, and $M^{\prime}=M \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}, g^{\prime \prime}\right\}$. The utilities of the goods are as follows.

- $u_{1}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=b-\epsilon, u_{1}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)=c-k(n-1) b-(b-\epsilon)$, and $u_{1}(g)=b$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$.
- For $i \in N^{\prime}, u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=0, u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)=c-k(n-1) a$, and $u_{i}(g)=a$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$.
- $u_{n}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)=c$, and $u_{n}(g)=u_{n}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=0$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$.

Note that $\left|N^{\prime}\right|=n-2 \geq 1,\left|M^{\prime}\right|=k(n-1) \geq\left|N^{\prime}\right|$, the utility of each good is non-negative, and $u_{i}(M)=c$ for all $i \in N$. Therefore, this is a valid normalized instance; moreover, it is positive-admitting since the allocation where agent 1 receives $g^{\prime}$, agent $n$ receives $g^{\prime \prime}$, and agent $i \in N^{\prime}$ each receives at least one good from $M^{\prime}$ gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Likewise, if $A_{n} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime \prime}\right\} \neq \varnothing$, then giving $A_{n} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime \prime}\right\}$ to agent 1 results in the same contradiction.

$$
\begin{aligned}

& \geq f(0)+f(c)+\sum_{i \in N \backslash\{j, n\}} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& =f(c)+f(0)+\sum_{i \in N \backslash\{j, n\}} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right) \\
& \geq f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)+f\left(u_{n}\left(A_{n}\right)\right)+\sum_{i \in N \backslash\{j, n\}} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right) \\

Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen, we have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get

$$
f((k+1) a)-f(k a) \leq f((k+1) b-\epsilon)-f(k b-\epsilon)
$$

contradicting (1). Therefore, $f$ satisfies Condition 1a.
With this lemma in hand, we are ready to prove Theorem 3.15.
Proof of Theorem 3.15. The implication (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b) follows from Lemmas 3.16 and 3.8, while the implication (b) $\Rightarrow$ (a) follows from the result of Caragiannis et al. [6].

We now address the case of two agents. Eckart et al. [9] showed that in this case, the $p$-mean rule guarantees EF1 for all $p \leq 0$, which implies that there is a larger class of additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1. Accordingly, our characterization in Theorem 3.15 does not work for two agents. The problem of finding a characterization for this case turns out to be rather challenging. We instead provide a necessary condition and a sufficient condition for the functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for normalized instances with two agents. Note that the sufficient condition in Proposition 3.18 is a generalization of the condition used by Eckart et al. [9, Lemma 3].

Proposition 3.17. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that for every positiveadmitting normalized instance with two agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1. Then, $f$ is strictly concave.

Proof. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $f$ is not strictly concave. We claim that there exist $c \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\delta \in(0, c)$ such that for all $\delta^{\prime} \in(0, \delta]$, it holds that $f(c) \leq 0.5 f\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 f\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)$. We first prove this claim. By definition, there exist $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ with $a<$ $b$ and $\tau \in(0,1)$ such that $f(\tau a+(1-\tau) b) \leq \tau f(a)+(1-\tau) f(b)$. Let $F(x)=f(x)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(x-a)$. Note that $F$ is continuous on $[a, b]$ and $F(a)=F(b)=f(a)$. By the extreme value theorem, $F$ attains a minimum in the interval $[a, b]$ at some $c \in[a, b]$, i.e., $F(x) \geq F(c)$
for all $x \in[a, b]$. If $c=a$ or $c=b$, then $c^{\prime}=\tau a+(1-\tau) b \in(a, b)$ is also a minimum, since

$$
\begin{aligned}
F\left(c^{\prime}\right) & =f\left(c^{\prime}\right)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\left(c^{\prime}-a\right) \\
& \leq \tau f(a)+(1-\tau) f(b)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\left(c^{\prime}-a\right) \\
& =\tau f(a)+(1-\tau) f(b)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(1-\tau)(b-a) \\
& =\tau f(a)+(1-\tau) f(b)-(1-\tau)(f(b)-f(a)) \\
& =f(a)(=F(a)=F(b))
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we may assume without loss of generality that $F$ attains a minimum at some $c \in(a, b)$. Let $\delta=\min \{c-a, b-c\}>0$. Then, for all $x \in[c-\delta, c+\delta]$, we have $F(x) \geq F(c)$. This means that for all $\delta^{\prime} \in(0, \delta]$, it holds that $F(c) \leq 0.5 F\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 F\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)$. Thus, for all $\delta^{\prime} \in(0, \delta]$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(c)= & F(c)+\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(c-a) \\
\leq & 0.5 F\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 F\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)+\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(c-a) \\
= & 0.5 F\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 F\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right) \\
& +0.5 \cdot \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\left(\left(c-\delta^{\prime}-a\right)+\left(c+\delta^{\prime}-a\right)\right) \\
= & 0.5\left(F\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\left(c-\delta^{\prime}-a\right)\right) \\
& +0.5\left(F\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)+\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\left(c+\delta^{\prime}-a\right)\right) \\
= & 0.5 f\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 f\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

proving the claim.
Now, let $c \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and $\delta \in(0, c)$ be given such that for all $\delta^{\prime} \in(0, \delta]$, we have $f(c) \leq 0.5 f\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 f\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)$. Consider an instance with two agents and $2\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ goods such that each good has utility $\delta^{\prime}=c /\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ to each agent. This instance is a normalized instance; moreover, it is positive-admitting since the allocation where every agent receives $\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ goods gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ be the allocation where each agent receives $\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ goods. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=2 f(c)$. Note that $\mathcal{A}$ is the only EF1 allocation; indeed, if some agent receives fewer than $\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ goods, then this agent is not EF1 towards the other agent who receives more than $\lceil c / \delta\rceil$ goods. Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, B_{2}\right)$ be the allocation such that agent 1 receives $\lceil c / \delta\rceil-1$ goods and agent 2 receives $\lceil c / \delta\rceil+1$ goods. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)=f\left(c-\delta^{\prime}\right)+$ $f\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is the only EF1 allocation, the additive welfarist rule with $f$ chooses (only) $\mathcal{A}$, and we have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)>$ $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)$. Simplifying the inequality, we get $f(c)>0.5 f(c-$ $\left.\delta^{\prime}\right)+0.5 f\left(c+\delta^{\prime}\right)$. However, since $\delta^{\prime}=c /\lceil c / \delta\rceil \leq c /(c / \delta)=\delta$, this contradicts the assumption on $f$. Therefore, $f$ is strictly concave.

Proposition 3.18. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 2. Then, for every positiveadmitting normalized instance with two agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.

Proof. Let a positive-admitting normalized instance with two agents be given, and let $U=u_{1}(M)=u_{2}(M)$. Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\mathcal{A}$ is not EF1. Without loss of generality, we may assume that agent 1 is not EF1 towards agent 2. Then, we have $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)<u_{1}\left(A_{2} \backslash\{g\}\right) \leq u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)$ for all $g \in A_{2}$, and thus $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)<U / 2$. Moreover, if $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)<U / 2$, then exchanging the two agents' bundles increases both agents' utilities of their own bundles, thereby increasing the value of $\sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Therefore, $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right) \geq U / 2$. Let $a=u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)$, $b=u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)$; note that $a<U / 2 \leq b$, and hence $\min \{a, b\}=a$.

Since $u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)>u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \geq 0$, there exists a good in $A_{2}$ with positive utility to agent 1 . Let $g^{\prime}=\arg \min _{g \in A_{2}, u_{1}(g)>0} u_{2}(g) / u_{1}(g)$. Let $B_{1}=A_{1} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}, B_{2}=A_{2} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}, c_{1}=u_{1}\left(B_{1}\right), d_{1}=u_{2}\left(B_{2}\right)$, $c_{2}=u_{1}\left(B_{2}\right)$, and $d_{2}=u_{2}\left(B_{1}\right)$.

We claim that $a b<c_{1} d_{1}$. By the choice of $g^{\prime}$, we have

$$
\frac{u_{2}\left(g^{\prime}\right)}{u_{1}\left(g^{\prime}\right)} \leq \frac{\sum_{g \in A_{2}, u_{1}(g)>0} u_{2}(g)}{\sum_{g \in A_{2}, u_{1}(g)>0} u_{1}(g)} \leq \frac{\sum_{g \in A_{2}} u_{2}(g)}{\sum_{g \in A_{2}} u_{1}(g)} \leq \frac{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)}{u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)}
$$

which gives $\left(b-d_{1}\right) /\left(c_{1}-a\right) \leq b / u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)$. On the other hand, since agent 1 is not EF1 towards agent 2 in $\mathcal{A}$, we have $u_{1}\left(A_{1} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)<$ $u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)$, or $c_{1}<u_{1}\left(A_{2}\right)$. Multiplying these two inequalities together and noting that the expressions on both sides of the inequalities are non-negative, we get $c_{1}\left(b-d_{1}\right) /\left(c_{1}-a\right)<b$. Simple algebraic manipulation gives us the desired inequality $a b<c_{1} d_{1}$.

We consider the following two cases.
Case 1: $a \leq d_{1}$. We claim that $a \leq \min \left\{c_{1}, d_{1}\right\}$. Note that $c_{1}-$ $a=u_{1}\left(g^{\prime}\right)>0$, and hence $a<c_{1}$. Moreover, we have $a \leq d_{1}$ by assumption. Therefore, $a \leq \min \left\{c_{1}, d_{1}\right\}$.

Now, since $\min \{a, b\}=a \leq \min \left\{c_{1}, d_{1}\right\}$ and $a b<c_{1} d_{1}$, Condition 2 implies that $f(a)+f(b)<f\left(c_{1}\right)+f\left(d_{1}\right)$. On the other hand, since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)$, where the right-hand side of the inequality corresponds to the allocation $\left(B_{1}, B_{2}\right)$. Substituting in the respective values, we get $f(a)+f(b) \geq f\left(c_{1}\right)+f\left(d_{1}\right)$, a contradiction.

Case 2: $a>d_{1}$. We claim that $a \leq \min \left\{c_{2}, d_{2}\right\}$. Since agent 1 is not EF1 towards agent 2 in $\mathcal{A}$, we have $a<c_{2}$. Moreover, it holds that $a+d_{2}>d_{1}+d_{2}=U$, and $a<U / 2$ implies that $a<U / 2<d_{2}$. Therefore, $a \leq \min \left\{c_{2}, d_{2}\right\}$.

We show that $a b<c_{2} d_{2}$. To this end, observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{2} d_{2} & =\left(U-c_{1}\right)\left(U-d_{1}\right) \\
& =U\left(U-c_{1}-d_{1}\right)+c_{1} d_{1} \\
& =U\left(c_{2}-d_{1}\right)+c_{1} d_{1} \\
& >U\left(a-d_{1}\right)+c_{1} d_{1} \\
& >c_{1} d_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality follows from $a<c_{2}$ and the second inequality from the assumption $a>d_{1}$. Therefore, $a b<c_{1} d_{1}<c_{2} d_{2}$.

Now, since $\min \{a, b\}=a \leq \min \left\{c_{2}, d_{2}\right\}$ and $a b<c_{2} d_{2}$, Condition 2 implies that $f(a)+f(b)<f\left(c_{2}\right)+f\left(d_{2}\right)$. On the other hand, since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{3-i}\right)\right)$, where the right-hand side of the inequality corresponds to the allocation $\left(B_{2}, B_{1}\right)$. Substituting
in the respective values, we get $f(a)+f(b) \geq f\left(c_{2}\right)+f\left(d_{2}\right)$, a contradiction.

Since we have reached a contradiction in both cases, we conclude that $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1.

We show in Appendix D. 1 that beyond the $p$-mean rules for $p \leq 0$, there are (infinitely many) other additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for normalized instances with two agents, and provide some insights on the extent to which the additive welfarist rules with the modified logarithmic function $\lambda_{c}$ and the modified harmonic number $h_{c}$ can ensure EF1 for such instances.

## 4 INTEGER-VALUED INSTANCES

In this section, we turn our attention to integer-valued instances, where the utility of each agent for each good must be a (non-negative) integer. For these instances, the MNW rule is no longer the unique additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1: the MHW rule exhibits the same property [17]. We shall explore the conditions for rules to satisfy this property, and provide several examples of such rules.

### 4.1 Identical-Good Instances

We begin with the class of (integer-valued) identical-good instances. We show that the functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for such instances are precisely those that satisfy Condition 3. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Condition 3 is similar to Condition 1 (which is the condition corresponding to real-valued identical-good instances), with the difference being that the values of $a$ and $b$ in the conditions are positive real numbers in Condition 1 and positive integers in Condition 3.

Theorem 4.1. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting integer-valued identical-good instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.
(b) $f$ satisfies Condition 3.

Due to the similarity between Conditions 1 and 3, the proof for (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b) in Theorem 4.1 follows similarly to that in the real-valued case (Lemma 3.2). To prove (b) $\Rightarrow$ (a), we show that Condition 3 implies Condition 3a, which in turn implies (a).

Lemma 4.2. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 3. Then, $f$ satisfies Condition 3a.

Proof. Let $k, \ell \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be given such that $\ell<k$. By applying Condition 3 repeatedly, we have $\Delta_{f, \ell}(b)>\Delta_{f, \ell+1}(a)>$ $\cdots>\Delta_{f, k}(a)$, so $f$ indeed satisfies Condition 3a.

Lemma 4.3. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 3a. Then, the statement in Theorem 4.1(a) holds.

Proof. Let a positive-admitting integer-valued identical-good instance be given, and let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\mathcal{A}$ is not EF1. Then, there exist two agents $i, j \in N$ such that agent $i$ envies agent $j$ by more than one good.

Hence, $0 \leq\left|A_{i}\right| \leq\left|A_{j}\right|-2$. Moreover, since the instance is integervalued and identical-good, we have for each $g \in M$ that $u_{i}(g)=b$ and $u_{j}(g)=a$ for some $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Let $k=\left|A_{j}\right|-1$ and $t=\left|A_{i}\right|$; note that $k, t \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ with $t<k$. We have $\sum_{r \in N} f\left(u_{r}\left(A_{r}\right)\right)=$ $f(t b)+f((k+1) a)+\sum_{r \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{r}\left(A_{r}\right)\right)$.

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that one good is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle. Then, $\sum_{r \in N} f\left(u_{r}\left(B_{r}\right)\right)=f((t+1) b)+f(k a)+\sum_{r \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{r}\left(A_{r}\right)\right)$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{r \in N} f\left(u_{r}\left(B_{r}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{r \in N} f\left(u_{r}\left(A_{r}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get

$$
f((t+1) b)-f(t b) \leq f((k+1) a)-f(k a)
$$

or equivalently, $\Delta_{f, t}(b) \leq \Delta_{f, k}(a)$, contradicting Condition 3a. Therefore, $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1.

Proof of Theorem 4.1. The implication (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b) follows similarly as Lemma 3.2, while the implication (b) $\Rightarrow$ (a) follows from Lemmas 4.2 and 4.3.

Since Conditions 1 and 1a are equivalent (see Theorem 3.1 and Lemmas 3.2, 3.3, and 3.8), one may be tempted to think that there is a condition analogous to Condition 1a that Condition 3 is equivalent to, perhaps " $\Delta_{f, k}$ is a constant function (on domain $\mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ ) for each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ ". However, this condition is too strong, and is not implied by Condition 3. ${ }^{9}$ Instead, we show that Condition 3 is equivalent to Condition 3b.

Proposition 4.4. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) $f$ satisfies Condition 3.
(b) $f$ satisfies Condition 3a.
(c) $f$ satisfies Condition $3 b$.

Proof. (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b): This follows from Lemma 4.2.
(b) $\Rightarrow$ (c): This follows directly by definition.
(c) $\Rightarrow$ (a): Let $f$ be a function that satisfies Condition 3b. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be given as in Condition 3. If $b=1$, then the left inequality of Condition 3b implies that $f$ satisfies Condition 3. If $b>1$ and $a=1$, then for $k=0$ we have $\Delta_{f, k}(b)=$ $f(b)-f(0)>f(2)-f(1)=\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$ where the inequality holds due to $f$ being strictly increasing, and for $k>0$ the right inequality of Condition 3b implies that $\Delta_{f, k}(b)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$; hence $f$ satisfies Condition 3. Therefore, it suffices to prove that $f$ satisfies Condition 3 for $a, b \geq 2$.

Let $K_{1}=(k+1) a-1, K_{2}=(k+1) b+1, K_{3}=(k+2) a-1$, and $K_{4}=k b+1$. By algebraic manipulation, we have $K_{1} K_{2}-K_{3} K_{4}=$ $a b-a-b$, which is non-negative for $a, b \geq 2$. This means that $K_{1} K_{2} \geq K_{3} K_{4}$. Hence, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{f, k}(b) & =\sum_{t=K_{4}-1}^{K_{3}-2} \Delta_{f, t}(1) \\
& >\sum_{t=K_{4}-1}^{K_{3}-2} \Delta_{f, t+1}\left(K_{3}\right) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \text { (since } f \text { satisfies Condition 3b) }
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]\[

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
=f\left(K_{2} K_{3}\right)-f\left(K_{4} K_{3}\right) & \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
\geq f\left(K_{3} K_{2}\right)-f\left(K_{1} K_{2}\right) & \text { (since } f \text { is strictly increasing) } \\
=\sum_{t=K_{1}}^{K_{3}-1} \Delta_{f, t}\left(K_{2}\right) & \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
>\sum_{t=K_{1}}^{K_{2}-1} \Delta_{f, t+1}(1) & \text { (since } f \text { satisfies Condition 3b) } \\
=\Delta_{f, k+1}(a), & \text { (by telescoping sum) }
\end{array}
$$
\]

which shows that $f$ satisfies Condition 3 .
We next give examples of additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for all integer-valued identical-good instances. We study two families of functions: modified logarithmic functions $\lambda_{c}$ and modified harmonic numbers $h_{c}$. By leveraging Proposition 4.4 and Theorem 4.1, we can determine which of these additive welfarist rules ensure EF1 for integer-valued identical-good instances.

Proposition 4.5. The function $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition $3 b$ if and only if $0 \leq c \leq 1$.

Proof. ( $\Leftarrow$ ) We show that $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3b for $0 \leq c \leq$ 1. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. By algebraic manipulation, we have $((k+1) a+c)(k+1+c)-((k+2) a+c)(k+c)=a(1-c)+c$. Since $a$ and at least one of $1-c$ and $c$ are positive, we have $a(1-c)+$ $c>0$. This implies that $((k+1) a+c)(k+1+c)>((k+2) a+$ $c)(k+c)$. Taking the logarithm on both sides and rearranging the inequality, we get $\log (k+1+c)-\log (k+c)>\log ((k+2) a+c)-$ $\log ((k+1) a+c)$. This gives $\lambda_{c}(k+1)-\lambda_{c}(k)>\lambda_{c}((k+2) a)-$ $\lambda_{c}((k+1) a)$, or $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k}(1)>\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k+1}(a)$, proving the left inequality of Condition 3b. For the right inequality of Condition 3b, observe that $((k+2) a+c)(k+2+c)-((k+1) a+c)(k+3+c)=a+c(a-1)>0$. By applying a similar method as above, we obtain $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k+1}(a)>$ $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k+2}(1)$, proving the right inequality.
$(\Rightarrow)$ We show that $\lambda_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 3b for $c>1$. Let $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be such that $a \geq c /(c-1)$. By algebraic manipulation, we have $(a+c)(1+c)-(2 a+c) c=a(1-c)+c \leq 0$, which implies that $(a+c)(1+c) \leq(2 a+c) c$. Taking the logarithm on both sides and rearranging the inequality, we get $\log (1+c)-\log c \leq \log (2 a+c)-$ $\log (a+c)$. This gives $\lambda_{c}(1)-\lambda_{c}(0) \leq \lambda_{c}(2 a)-\lambda_{c}(a)$, or $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, 0}(1) \leq$ $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, 1}(a)$, violating the left inequality of Condition 3b.

Proposition 4.6. The function $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3b if and only if $-1 \leq c \leq 1 / \log 2-1(\approx 0.443)$.

The proof of Proposition 4.6 involves complex calculations and is deferred to Appendix A.1.

Propositions 4.5 and 4.6 show that beyond the MNW rule and the MHW rule, many other additive welfarist rules guarantee EF1 for integer-valued identical-good instances. We provide more discussion in Appendix D.2.

### 4.2 Binary Instances

Next, we consider binary instances, where each good is worth either 0 or 1 to each agent. We show that the functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for all binary instances are those that satisfy Condition 4, which is equivalent to the function being strictly concave in the domain of non-negative integers.


[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ Indeed, the MHW rule-which corresponds to the function $h_{0}$-guarantees EF1 for integer-valued instances [17], but $\Delta_{h_{0}, 1}$ is not a constant function as $\Delta_{h_{0}, 1}(1)=$ $h_{0}(2)-h_{0}(1)=1 / 2<7 / 12=h_{0}(4)-h_{0}(2)=\Delta_{h_{0}, 1}(2)$.

Theorem 4.7. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting binary instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.
(b) $f$ satisfies Condition 4.

Proof. (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b): Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. Consider an instance with $n$ agents and $2 k+n$ goods, and let $M^{\prime}=\left\{g_{1}, \ldots, g_{2 k+2}\right\}$. The utilities of the goods are as follows.

- For $i \in\{1,2\}, u_{i}(g)=1$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$, and $u_{i}(g)=0$ otherwise.
- For $i \in\{3, \ldots, n\}, u_{i}\left(g_{2 k+i}\right)=1$, and $u_{i}(g)=0$ for all other $g \in M$.

This instance is a binary instance; moreover, it is positive-admitting since any allocation where each agent $i \in N$ receives $g_{2 k+i}$ gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Each good must be allocated to an agent who has utility 1 for the good; otherwise, transferring such a good to an agent who has utility 1 for the good increases the value of $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$, contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Accordingly, the goods in $M^{\prime}$ are allocated to agent 1 and 2 , and for each $i \in\{3, \ldots, n\}, g_{2 k+i}$ is allocated to agent $i$.

Recall that $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1 since it is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. We claim that agent 1 and 2 each receives exactly $k+1$ goods from $M^{\prime}$. If not, then one of them receives at most $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$, and will envy the other agent (who receives at least $k+2$ goods from $M^{\prime}$ ) by more than one good, making the allocation not EF1 and contradicting our assumption. Then, we have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=2 f(k+1)+(n-2) f(1)$.

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the allocation such that agent 1 receives $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$, agent 2 receives $k+2$ goods from $M^{\prime}$, and for each $i \in\{3, \ldots, n\}$, agent $i$ receives $g_{2 k+i}$. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)=$ $f(k)+f(k+2)+(n-2) f(1)$. Note that $\mathcal{B}$ is not EF1, and cannot be chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Therefore, we have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)>\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get

$$
f(k+1)-f(k)>f(k+2)-f(k+1)
$$

or equivalently, $\Delta_{f, k}(1)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(1)$. Since $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ was arbitrarily chosen, $\Delta_{f, k}(1)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(1)$ holds for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. Therefore, $f$ satisfies Condition 4.
(b) $\Rightarrow$ (a): Let a positive-admitting binary instance with $n$ agents be given, and let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\mathcal{A}$ is not EF1. Then, there exist $i, j \in N$ such that agent $i$ envies agent $j$ by more than one good, i.e., $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)<u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\{g\}\right)$ for all $g \in A_{j}$. Note that we must have $u_{i}(g) \leq u_{j}(g)$ for all $g \in A_{j}$. Indeed, otherwise we have $u_{i}(g)=1$ and $u_{j}(g)=0$, and transferring $g$ from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle increases $f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$ and does not decrease $f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)$, thereby increasing $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Moreover, since $u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right)>0$, there exists $g^{\prime} \in A_{j}$ such that $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=1$ (and hence $u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=1$ ).

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that $g^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle, i.e., $B_{i}=$ $A_{i} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}, B_{j}=A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}$, and $B_{k}=A_{k}$ for all $k \in N \backslash\{i, j\}$. Note that $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)<u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)=u_{i}\left(B_{j}\right)$, and that $u_{i}\left(B_{j}\right) \leq u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)$ since $u_{i}(g) \leq u_{j}(g)$ for all $g \in B_{j}$. Therefore, $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)<u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)$. By Condition 4, it holds that $\Delta_{f, u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)}(1)>\cdots>\Delta_{f, u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)}(1)$. On the other hand, we have $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(B_{k}\right)\right)=f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)+f\left(u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)\right)+$ $\sum_{k \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(B_{k}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get

$$
f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)-f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right) \leq f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)-f\left(u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)\right)
$$

or equivalently, $\Delta_{f, u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)}(1) \leq \Delta_{f, u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)}(1)$, a contradiction. Therefore, $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1.

Condition 4 is weaker than Condition 3. Indeed, if $f$ satisfies Condition 3, then it satisfies Condition 4 by definition. However, the converse is not true: the function $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$ satisfies Condition 4, but it does not satisfy Condition 3 since $\Delta_{f, 0}(1)=1$ is not greater than $\Delta_{f, 1}(6)=1.01$. This means that each additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1 for every positive-admitting integer-valued identical-good instance also guarantees EF1 for every positive-admitting binary instance, but the converse does not hold.

Proposition 4.8. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. If $f$ satisfies Condition 3, then it satisfies Condition 4.

We mentioned earlier that Condition 4 is equivalent to the function being strictly concave in the domain of non-negative integers. On the other hand, the function $\varphi_{p}$ defining the $p$-mean rule is strictly concave if and only if $p<1$. We prove that, indeed, $\varphi_{p}$ satisfies Condition 4 exactly when $p<1$.

Proposition 4.9. The function $\varphi_{p}$ satisfies Condition 4 if and only if $p<1$.

Proof. ( $\Rightarrow$ ) Let $p \geq 1$. Then, $\varphi_{p}(x)=x^{p}$ and so $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, k}(1)=$ $(k+1)^{p}-k^{p}$. Note that $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 0}(1)=1^{p}-0^{p}=1$. Furthermore, $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 1}(1)=2^{p}-1^{p} \geq 2-1=1$ since $p \geq 1$. Hence, $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, k}(1) \leq$ $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, k+1}(1)$ when $k=0$, so $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 4.
$(\Leftarrow)$ Let $p<1$. We first prove that, for any $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, the second derivative $\varphi_{p}^{\prime \prime}(x)$ is always negative (although not necessarily finite). Note that $\varphi_{p}^{\prime}(x)=C_{p} x^{p-1}$ for some positive constant $C_{p}$, where $C_{p}=p$ if $0<p<1, C_{p}=1$ if $p=0$, and $C_{p}=-p$ if $p<0$. Hence, $\varphi_{p}^{\prime \prime}(x)=C_{p}(p-1) x^{p-2}$. Since $p<1$, we have $C_{p}(p-1)<0$. Then, for all $x \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, \varphi_{p}^{\prime \prime}(x)<0$. This means that $\varphi_{p}$ is strictly concave in the non-negative real domain.

Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. If $p \leq 0$ and $k=0$, then $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 0}(1)=\infty>\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 1}(1)$. We now assume that $p>0$ or $k>0$, and so $\varphi_{p}(k), \varphi_{p}(k+1), \varphi_{p}(k+$ 2) are all finite. Since $\varphi_{p}$ is strictly concave in the non-negative real domain, by letting $x=k, y=k+2$, and $\alpha=1 / 2$ in the definition of strict concavity, we get $\varphi_{p}(k+1)>\varphi_{p}(k) / 2+\varphi_{p}(k+2) / 2$. Hence, $2 \varphi_{p}(k+1)>\varphi_{p}(k)+\varphi_{p}(k+2)$, which implies that $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, k}(1)=$ $\varphi_{p}(k+1)-\varphi_{p}(k)>\varphi_{p}(k+2)-\varphi_{p}(k+1)=\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, k+1}(1)$. It follows that $\varphi_{p}$ satisfies Condition 4.

### 4.3 Two-Value Instances

We now consider integer-valued instances which are two-value, a strict generalization of binary instances. Recall from Section 3.2 that the classes of identical-good instances and two-value instances are not subclasses of each other (except when $n=2$ ). Therefore, the techniques used in Section 4.1 cannot be used in this section. ${ }^{10}$

We show that the characterization for integer-valued two-value instances is given by Condition 5 . Before we state the characterization, we examine the relationship between Conditions 3 and 5.

Proposition 4.10. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function.
(i) If $f$ satisfies Condition 5, then $f$ satisfies Condition 3.
(ii) If $f$ satisfies Condition 3 and the property that for each $k \in$ $\mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, the function $\Delta_{f, k}$ is either non-decreasing or non-increasing on the domain of positive integers, then $f$ satisfies Condition 5 .

Proof. (i) Substituting $b=1, t=k$, and $r=0$ into Condition 5 gives Condition 3b, which is equivalent to Condition 3 by Proposition 4.4.
(ii) Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $k, t, r \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $a \geq b$ and $(k+$ $1) b>t b+r a$. Note that $f$ trivially satisfies the right inequality of Condition 5 ; therefore, it suffices to prove the left inequality. Since $f$ satisfies Condition 3, Proposition 4.4 implies that $f$ satisfies Condition 3a.

If $\Delta_{f, k+1}$ is non-increasing, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f((t+1) b+r a)-f(t b+r a) \\
& \quad=\sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{f, t b+r a+t}(1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \quad>\sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{f,(k+1) b+t}(1) \\
& \quad \text { (by Condition 3a and }(k+1) b>t b+r a) \\
& \quad=f((k+2) b)-f((k+1) b) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \quad=\Delta_{f, k+1}(b) \\
& \quad \geq \Delta_{f, k+1}(a)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality holds because $\Delta_{f, k+1}$ is non-increasing and $a \geq b$. This proves the left inequality of Condition 5.

On the other hand, if $\Delta_{f, k+1}$ is non-decreasing, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f((t+1) b+r a)-f(t b+r a) \\
& \quad=\sum_{t=0}^{k-1} \Delta_{f, t b+r a+t}(1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \quad>\sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{f,(k+1) b+t}(a) \\
& \quad \text { (by Condition 3a and }(k+1) b>t b+r a) \\
& \quad=f((k+2) b a)-f((k+1) b a) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \quad=\Delta_{f, k+1}(a b) \\
& \quad \geq \Delta_{f, k+1}(a)
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]where the last inequality holds because $\Delta_{f, k+1}$ is non-decreasing and $a b \geq a$. This proves the left inequality of Condition 5 .

We now state the characterization for integer-valued two-value instances.

Theorem 4.11. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. Then, the following statements are equivalent:
(a) For every positive-admitting integer-valued two-value instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is $E F 1$.
(b) $f$ satisfies Condition 5.

Proof. (a) $\Rightarrow$ (b): By a similar proof as that in Lemma 3.2, $f$ satisfies Condition 3, which implies that $f$ satisfies the right inequality of Condition 5. Therefore, it suffices to show that $f$ satisfies the left inequality of Condition 5. Note also that since $f$ satisfies Condition 3, by Proposition 4.4, $f$ satisfies Condition 3a as well.

Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $k, t, r \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ be given such that $a \geq b$ and $(k+$ $1) b>t b+r a$. If $a=b$, then by Condition 3a, we have $\Delta_{f, t+r}(a)>$ $\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$, which implies $f((t+1) a+r a)-f(t a+r a)>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$, and thus $f$ satisfies Condition 5. Therefore, we shall consider the case $a>b$.

Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $f((t+1) b+r a)-$ $f(t b+r a) \leq \Delta_{f, k+1}(a)$. Consider an instance with $n$ agents and $(k+1)(n-1) \cdot t+t+1$ goods, and let $M^{\prime}=\{1, \ldots, r\}$. The utilities of the goods are as follows.

- $u_{1}(g)=a$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$, and $u_{1}(g)=b$ otherwise.
- For $i \in\{2, \ldots, n\}, u_{i}(g)=a$ for all $g \in M$.

This instance is an integer-valued two-value instance; moreover, it is positive-admitting since there are at least $n$ goods, and an allocation where every agent receives at least one good gives positive utility to every agent.

Among all allocations chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation with the smallest value of $\left|A_{1}\right|$. By assumption, $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1. We claim that $\left|A_{1}\right| \geq t+r+1$. If $\left|A_{1}\right| \leq t+r$, then there are more than $(k+1)(n-1)$ goods allocated to the agents in $N \backslash\{1\}$, and hence some agent $i \in N \backslash\{1\}$ receives at least $k+2$ goods. Then, we have $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \leq t b+r a<(k+1) b \leq$ $u_{1}\left(A_{1} \backslash\{g\}\right)$ for all $g \in A_{i}$, contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1. Now, since $\left|A_{1}\right| \geq t+r+1>r=\left|M^{\prime}\right|$, there exists a good $g^{\prime} \in M \backslash M^{\prime}$ in agent 1's bundle. Moreover, every good in $M^{\prime}$ must be in $A_{1}$. Indeed, if some good $g \in M^{\prime}$ is in agent $i$ 's bundle for some $i \in N \backslash\{1\}$, then exchanging $g$ with $g^{\prime}$ increases agent 1 's utility for her own bundle and does not decrease other agents' utilities for their own bundles, thereby increasing $\sum_{j \in N} u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. This gives $K:=u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \geq(t+1) b+r a$.

Since agent 1 has at least $t+r+1$ goods, at most $(k+1)(n-1)$ goods are allocated to the agents in $N \backslash\{1\}$. In particular, there exists an agent $i \in N \backslash\{1\}$ who has at most $k+1$ goods, and thus $L:=$ $\left|A_{i}\right| \leq k+1$. Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that $g^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent 1 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle, i.e., $B_{1}=A_{1} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}, B_{i}=A_{i} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}$, and $B_{j}=A_{j}$ for all $j \in N \backslash\{1, i\}$. Since $\left|B_{1}\right|<\left|A_{1}\right|, \mathcal{B}$ cannot be chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, and hence $\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)>\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)\right)$. (b) $\Rightarrow$ (a): Let a positive-admitting integer-valued two-value instance be given, and let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Since the instance is twovalue, there exist distinct $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $u_{i}(g) \in\{a, b\}$ for all $i \in N$ and $g \in M$; assume without loss of generality that $a>b$. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\mathcal{A}$ is not EF1. Then, there exist two agents $i, j \in N$ such that agent $i$ envies agent $j$ by more than one good. Note that $f$ satisfies Condition 3 by Proposition 4.10(a), and so $f$ also satisfies Condition 3a by Proposition 4.4.

We consider the following two cases.
Case 1: $u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right) \leq u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)$. We show that there exists $g^{\prime} \in A_{j}$ such that $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right) \geq u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)$. Since agent $i$ is not EF1 towards agent $j$, we have $\left|A_{j}\right| \geq 2$, and $b\left|A_{j}\right|=u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right)>u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \geq 0$ implies that $a>b>0$. Moreover, $u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\{g\}\right)>u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)$ for any $g \in A_{j}$, which implies $(k+1) b>t b+r a$. $$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right) & =f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)+f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right) \\
& =f(t b+r a)+f((k+2) a)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that one good is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle. Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right)=f((t+1) b+r a) & +f((k+1) a) \\
& +\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f((t+1) b+r a)+f((k+1) a) \leq f(t b+r a)+f((k+2) a)$, violating Condition 5. Therefore, there exists $g^{\prime} \in A_{j}$ such that $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right) \geq u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)$.
