In either case, we have $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)$ and $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)>0$. Let $K=u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)$ and $L=u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime \prime}\right\}\right)$, and note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
K & =u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \\
& <u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime \prime}\right\}\right) \quad \text { (since agent } i \text { is not EF1 towards agent } j \text { ) } \\
& =u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right)-u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \\
& \leq u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)-u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \\
& \left(\text { since } u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right) \leq u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right) \text { and } u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \\
& =u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime \prime}\right\}\right) \\
& =L
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(K+u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)-f(K) \\
& =\sum_{t=0}^{u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)-1} \Delta_{f, K+t}(1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& >\sum_{t=0}^{u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)-1} \Delta_{f, L+t}(1) \\

& \text { (since } u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right) \text { and } f \text { is increasing) }

$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)=f(K)+f\left(L+u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)

$$

$$

Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f\left(K+u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)-f(K) \leq f\left(L+u_{j}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)-f(L)$, which is a contradiction.

On the other hand, we have

$$
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)=f(0)+f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
$$

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that $g^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right)=f\left(u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)\right) & +f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)\right) \\
& +\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f\left(u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)\right)-f(0) \leq f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)-f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)\right)$, which is a contradiction. Therefore, $\left|A_{i}\right|>0$.

Next, we show that $u_{i}(g)=a$ for all $g \in A_{i}$. If there exists a good $g^{\prime \prime} \in A_{i}$ such that $u_{i}\left(g^{\prime \prime}\right)=b$, then exchanging $g^{\prime}$ with $g^{\prime \prime}$ increases agent $i$ 's utility for her own bundle and does not decrease other agents' utilities for their own bundles, thereby increasing $\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. This shows that $u_{i}(g)=a$ for all $g \in A_{i}$, and hence $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)=a\left|A_{i}\right|>0$.

Let $K=u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)=a\left|A_{i}\right|$ and $L=u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)$. Note that $a\left|A_{i}\right|=$ $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)<u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right) \leq a\left(\left|A_{j}\right|-1\right)$ and hence $\left|A_{i}\right|<\left|A_{j}\right|-1$. Moreover, $L=u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right) \geq b\left(\left|A_{j}\right|-1\right)$ since each good has utility at least $b$. Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(K+a)-f(K) \\
& \quad=f\left(a\left(\left|A_{i}\right|+1\right)\right)-f\left(a\left|A_{i}\right|\right) \\
& \quad=\Delta_{f,\left|A_{i}\right|}(a) \\
& \quad>\Delta_{f,\left|A_{j}\right|-1}(b) \quad \text { (by Condition 3a and }\left|A_{i}\right|<\left|A_{j}\right|-1) \\
& \quad=f\left(b\left|A_{j}\right|\right)-f\left(b\left(\left|A_{j}\right|-1\right)\right) \\
& \quad=\sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{f, b\left(\left|A_{j}\right|-1\right)+t}(1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \quad \geq \sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{f, L+t}(1) \quad \text { (by Condition 3a and } L \geq b\left(\left|A_{j}\right|-1\right) \text { ) } \\
& \quad=f(L+b)-f(L) . \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) }
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)=f(K)+f(L+b)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
$$

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that $g^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle. We have

$$
\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right)=f(K+a)+f(L)+\sum_{s \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)
$$

Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we have $\sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(B_{s}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{s \in N} f\left(u_{s}\left(A_{s}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f(K+a)-f(K) \leq f(L+b)=f(L)$, which is a contradiction.

Since we have reached a contradiction in both cases, we conclude that $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1.

Proposition 4.10 says that Condition 5 is stronger than Condition 3. Therefore, Theorem 4.11 implies that every additive welfarist rule that guarantees EF1 for every positive-admitting integervalued two-value instance also guarantees EF1 for every positiveadmitting integer-valued identical-good instance, even though these two classes of instances are not subclasses of each other.

Next, we give examples of additive welfarist rules that ensure EF1 for all integer-valued two-value instances. We use Propositions $4.5,4.6$, and 4.10 to prove these results.

Proposition 4.12. The function $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5 if and only if $0 \leq c \leq 1$.

Proof. ( $\Leftrightarrow$ ) We show that $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5 for $0 \leq c \leq 1$. By Propositions 4.4 and 4.5, $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3. By Proposition 4.10, it suffices to prove that $\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k}$ is non-decreasing on the domain of positive integers for each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. For each positive integer $x$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{\lambda_{c}, k}(x) & =\lambda_{c}((k+1) x)-\lambda_{c}(k x) \\
& =\log ((k+1) x+c)-\log (k x+c) \\
& =\log \left(\frac{(k+1) x+c}{k x+c}\right) \\
& =\log \left(1+\frac{1}{k+c / x}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is non-decreasing in $x$. Therefore, $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5.
$(\Rightarrow)$ Since $\lambda_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 3 for $c>1$ by Proposition 4.5, it does not satisfy Condition 5 by Proposition 4.10.

Proposition 4.13. The function $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5 if and only if $-1 \leq c \leq 1 / \log 2-1(\approx 0.443)$.

The proof of Proposition 4.13 involves complex calculations and is deferred to Appendix A.2.

### 4.4 General Integer-Valued Instances

Finally, we consider the class of all integer-valued instances. It turns out to be challenging to find an exact characterization for this class of instances. Instead, we provide a necessary condition in the form of Condition 6 a and a sufficient condition in the form of Condition 6 b.

Proposition 4.14. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function such that for every positiveadmitting integer-valued instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1. Then, $f$ satisfies Condition 6a.

Proof. Let $k, a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be given. Consider an instance with $n$ agents and $k n+1$ goods, and let $M^{\prime}=M \backslash\left\{g_{1}\right\}$. The utilities of the goods are as follows.

- $u_{1}\left(g_{1}\right)=b-1$ and $u_{1}(g)=b$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$.
- For $i \in N \backslash\{1\}, u_{i}\left(g_{1}\right)=0$ and $u_{i}(g)=a$ for $g \in M^{\prime}$.

This instance is an integer-valued instance; moreover, it is positiveadmitting since an allocation where every agent has $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$ gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. We must have $g_{1} \in A_{1}$. Indeed, if $g_{1}$ is in $A_{i}$ for some $i \in N \backslash\{1\}$, then transferring $g_{1}$ to agent 1 increases the value of $f\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)\right)$ and does not decrease $f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$, thereby increasing $\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$.

Recall that $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1. We claim that every agent receives exactly $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$. If not, then some agent receives fewer than $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$, and envies another agent who receives more than $k$ goods from $M^{\prime}$ by more than one good, making $\mathcal{A}$ not EF1. Therefore, we have $\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)=f((k+1) b-1)+(n-1) f(k a)$.

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that one good from $M^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent 1's bundle to agent 2's bundle. We have $\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)\right)=f(k b-1)+f((k+1) a)+$ $(n-2) f(k a)$. Since $\mathcal{B}$ is not EF1, $\mathcal{B}$ cannot be chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Therefore, $\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)>\sum_{j \in N} f\left(u_{j}\left(B_{j}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f((k+1) b-1)-f(k b-1)>\Delta_{f, k}(a)$. Since $k, a, b$ were arbitrarily chosen, $f((k+1) b-1)-f(k b-1)>$ $\Delta_{f, k}(a)$ holds for all $k, a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Therefore, $f$ satisfies Condition 6 a .

Proposition 4.15. Let $n \geq 2$ be given, and let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 6b. Then, for every positive-admitting integer-valued instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1.

Proof. Let a positive-admitting integer-valued instance with $n$ agents be given, and let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\mathcal{A}$ is not EF1. Then, there exist distinct $i, j \in N$ such that agent $i$ envies agent $j$ by more than one good, i.e., $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)<$ $u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\{g\}\right)$ for all $g \in A_{j}$. Since the instance is integer-valued, we have $u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \leq u_{i}\left(A_{j} \backslash\{g\}\right)-1$ for all $g \in A_{j}$, or equivalently, $u_{i}\left(A_{i} \cup\{g\}\right)+1 \leq u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right)$.

Since $u_{i}\left(A_{j}\right)>u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \geq 0$, there exists a good in $A_{j}$ with positive utility to agent $i$. Let $g^{\prime}=\arg \min _{g \in A_{j}, u_{i}(g)>0} u_{j}(g) / u_{i}(g)$. Note that $u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)>0$. Indeed, if $u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)=0$, then transferring $g^{\prime}$ from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle increases $f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$ and does not decrease $f\left(u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)\right)$, thereby increasing $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$.

Let $a=u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right), b=u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right), x=u_{j}\left(A_{j} \backslash\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)$, and $y=u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)$. Note that $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$, and that $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)=$ $f(y)+f(x+a)+\sum_{k \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$. By the choice of $g^{\prime}$, we have

$$
\frac{u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)}{u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)} \leq \frac{\sum_{g \in A_{j}, u_{i}(g)>0} u_{j}(g)}{\sum_{g \in A_{j}, u_{i}(g)>0} u_{i}(g)} \leq \frac{u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)}{u_{i}\left(A_{j} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)+1}
$$

this implies that

$$
\frac{x+a}{a}=\frac{u_{j}\left(A_{j}\right)}{u_{j}\left(g^{\prime}\right)} \geq \frac{u_{i}\left(A_{i} \cup\left\{g^{\prime}\right\}\right)+1}{u_{i}\left(g^{\prime}\right)}=\frac{y+b+1}{b}
$$

or $x / a \geq(y+1) / b$. By Condition 6 b , we have $f(y+b)-f(y)>$ $f(x+a)-f(x)$.

Let $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ be the same allocation as $\mathcal{A}$ except that $g^{\prime}$ is transferred from agent $j$ 's bundle to agent $i$ 's bundle. Then, $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(B_{k}\right)\right)=f(y+b)+f(x)+\sum_{k \in N \backslash\{i, j\}} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$, we must have $\sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(B_{k}\right)\right) \leq \sum_{k \in N} f\left(u_{k}\left(A_{k}\right)\right)$. Rearranging the terms, we get $f(y+b)-f(y) \leq f(x+a)-f(x)$, which contradicts Condition 6 b. Therefore, $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1.

We demonstrate that the necessary condition given as Condition 6 a is fairly tight, in the sense that it is stronger than Condition 5, which characterizes the functions defining the additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for integer-valued two-value instances.

Proposition 4.16. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function. If $f$ satisfies Condition 6a, then it satisfies Condition 5.

Proof. When $a=b=1$ in Condition 6a, we have $\Delta_{f, k-1}(1)=$ $f(k)-f(k-1)>\Delta_{f, k}(1)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, which is Condition 4. This implies that $f$ satisfies Condition 4.
Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $k, t, r \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ be given such that $a \geq b$ and $(k+1) b>t b+r a$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f((t+1) b+r a)-f(t b+r a) & \\
=\sum_{t=0}^{k-1} \Delta_{f, t b+r a+t}(1) & \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
\geq \sum_{t=0}^{k-1} \Delta_{f,(k+1) b-1+t}(1) & \\
& \text { (by Condition } 4 \text { and }(k+1) b-1 \geq t b+r a) \\
=f((k+2) b-1)-f((k+1) b-1) & \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
>\Delta_{f, k+1}(a), & \text { (by Condition 6a) }
\end{aligned}
$$

which establishes the left inequality of Condition 5. Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{f, k+1}(a) \\
& =\sum_{t=0}^{a-1} \Delta_{f,(k+1) a+t}(1) \\
& \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& \geq \sum_{t=0}^{a-1} \Delta_{f,(k+2) a-1+t}(1) \\
& \text { (by Condition } 4 \text { and }(k+2) a-1 \geq(k+1) a) \\
& =f((k+3) a-1)-f((k+2) a-1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& >\Delta_{f, k+2}(1) \text { (by Condition 6a) }
\end{aligned}
$$

establishing the right inequality of Condition 5.
We now present some examples. We show that just like for the subclasses of integer-valued identical-good instances (Proposition 4.5), binary instances (Proposition 4.8), and integer-valued two-value instances (Proposition 4.12), the additive welfarist rule with function $\lambda_{c}$ for $0 \leq c \leq 1$ guarantees EF1 for all integer-valued instances.

Proposition 4.17. The function $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 6b if and only if $0 \leq c \leq 1$.

Proof. $(\Leftrightarrow)$ We show that $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 6 b for $0 \leq c \leq$ 1. Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $x / a \geq(y+1) / b$. Note that $x \geq a(y+1) / b>0$.

If $y=c=0$, then $\lambda_{c}(y)=-\infty$, and hence $\lambda_{c}(y+b)-\lambda_{c}(y)>$ $\lambda_{c}(x+a)-\lambda_{c}(x)$ holds since the left-hand side is $\infty$ while the righthand side is finite, and hence Condition $6 b$ is satisfied. Therefore, we shall consider the case $y+c>0$.

Now, we have

$$
\lambda_{c}(y+b)-\lambda_{c}(y)=\log \left(\frac{y+b+c}{y+c}\right)=\log \left(1+\frac{b}{y+c}\right)
$$

and

$$
\lambda_{c}(x+a)-\lambda_{c}(x)=\log \left(\frac{x+a+c}{x+c}\right)=\log \left(1+\frac{a}{x+c}\right)
$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\frac{x+c}{a} \geq \frac{x}{a} \geq \frac{y+1}{b} \geq \frac{y+c}{b}
$$

where the first inequality is strict if $c>0$, and the last inequality is strict if $c<1$; therefore, it holds that $(x+c) / a>(y+c) / b$. This implies that $b /(y+c)>a /(x+c)$. Since $\log$ is an increasing function, we have $\lambda_{c}(y+b)-\lambda_{c}(y)>\lambda_{c}(x+a)-\lambda_{c}(x)$. Since $a, b, x, y$ were arbitrarily chosen, $\lambda_{c}(y+b)-\lambda_{c}(y)>\lambda_{c}(x+a)-\lambda_{c}(x)$ holds for all $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ such that $x / a \geq(y+1) / b$. Therefore, $\lambda_{c}$ satisfies Condition 6 b.
$(\Rightarrow)$ We show that $\lambda_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 6 b for $c>1$. By Propositions 4.4 and 4.5, $\lambda_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 3, and by Theorem 4.1, there exists a positive-admitting integer-valued (identical-good) instance with $n \geq 2$ agents such that not every allocation chosen by the welfarist rule with $f$ is EF1. Then, by the contraposition of Proposition 4.15, $\lambda_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 6 b.

On the other hand, leveraging Condition 6a, we show that the additive welfarist rule with function $h_{c}$ for $-1 \leq c<-1 / 2$ does not guarantee EF1 for the class of all integer-valued instances. This stands in contrast to integer-valued identical-good instances (Proposition 4.6), binary instances (Proposition 4.8), and integer-valued two-value instances (Proposition 4.13).

Proposition 4.18. The function $h_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 6 a when $-1 \leq c<-1 / 2$.

To prove Proposition 4.18, we make use of the following lemma.
Lemma 4.19. Let $f(x)=\frac{1}{\log ((x+1) / x)}-(x+1)$. Then,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)=-1 / 2
$$

Proof. By Taylor's theorem, for all large enough $x$,

$$
\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}} \leq \log \left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right) \leq \frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 x^{3}}
$$

and so

$$
\frac{1}{\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}}-(x+1) \geq f(x) \geq \frac{1}{\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 x^{3}}}-(x+1)
$$

Now, we have

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{1}{\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}}-(x+1)\right)=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{-1+\frac{1}{x}}{2-\frac{1}{x}}\right)=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

and

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{1}{\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 x^{3}}}-(x+1)\right)=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{-3+\frac{1}{x}-\frac{2}{x^{2}}}{6-\frac{3}{x}+\frac{2}{x^{2}}}\right)=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

By the squeeze theorem, we get the required limit.
Proof of Proposition 4.18. Let $-1 \leq c<-1 / 2$, and let $f(x)=$ $\frac{1}{\log ((x+1) / x)}-(x+1)$. By Lemmas 4.19 and A.1, $f$ is strictly increasing on the integer domain and its limit when $x \rightarrow \infty$ is equal to $-1 / 2$, so there exists $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $f(k)>c$. This implies that $1 /(k+1+c)>\log ((k+1) / k)$. Since $\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)=h_{c}(k+1)-h_{c}(k)=$ $1 /(k+1+c)$, it holds that $\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)>\log ((k+1) / k)$.

On the other hand, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} & \left(h_{c}((k+1) b-1)-h_{c}(k b-1)\right) \\
& =\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty}(\log ((k+1) b+c)-\log (k b+c)) \quad \text { (by Lemma A.3) } \\
& =\log \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality follows from the proof of Lemma A.4.
Then, by definition of limit, there exists $b \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that

$$
h_{c}((k+1) b-1)-h_{c}(k b-1)<\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)
$$

Thus, Condition 6 a is not satisfied.

## 5 CONCLUSION

In this paper, we have characterized additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 allocations for various classes of instances. In the real-valued case, we strengthened the result of Suksompong [20] by showing that only the maximum Nash welfare (MNW) rule ensures EF1 even for the most restricted class of identical-good instances. This indicates that the unique fairness of MNW stems from its scale-invariance, ${ }^{11}$ since for normalized identical-good instances, an additive welfarist rule with any strictly concave function $f$ guarantees EF1. On the other hand, in the practically important case where all values are integers, we demonstrated that even for the most general setting with no additional restrictions, there is a wide range of additive welfarist rules that always return EF1 allocations.

Since we have established the existence of several alternatives that perform as well as MNW in terms of guaranteeing EF1 allocations for integer-valued instances, a natural follow-up would be to compare these rules with respect to other measures, both to MNW and to one another. As illustrated in Example 1.1, some additive welfarist rules may produce more preferable allocations for certain instances than others. It would be interesting to formalize this observation, for example, by comparing their prices in terms of social welfare, in the same vein as the "price of fairness" [3, 7, 14].

Other possible future directions include completely characterizing additive welfarist rules for normalized instances with two agents (Section 3.3) and for general integer-valued instances (Section 4.4) by tightening their respective necessary and sufficient conditions. Obtaining characterizations of welfarist rules that are not necessarily additive is also a possible extension of our work. Beyond EF1, one could consider other fairness notions from the

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{11}$ That is, scaling the utility function of an agent by a constant factor does not change the outcome of the MNW rule.

literature, such as proportionality up to one good (PROP1). Finally, another intriguing avenue is to study the problem of computing (or approximating) an allocation produced by various additive welfarist rules, as has been done extensively for the MNW rule [1, 2, $8,13]$.

## A OMITTED PROOFS
## A. 1 Proof of Proposition 4.6

We shall prove Proposition 4.6 via a series of intermediate results.
Lemma A.1. Let $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ be such that $x<y$. Then,

$$
\frac{1}{\log ((x+1) / x)}-x<\frac{1}{\log ((y+1) / y)}-y
$$

Proof. Let $f(z)=\frac{1}{\log ((z+1) / z)}-z$ be defined on $z \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$. We have

$$
f^{\prime}(z)=\frac{1}{z(z+1)\left(\log \left(\frac{z+1}{z}\right)\right)^{2}}-1
$$

We first show that $f^{\prime}(z)>0$ for all $z \geq 7$.
Let $z \geq 7$. By Taylor's theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \left(1+\frac{1}{z}\right) & =\sum_{t=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{t+1}}{t z^{t}} \\
& =\frac{1}{z}-\frac{1}{2 z^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 z^{3}}-\sum_{t=2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2 t z^{2 t}}-\frac{1}{(2 t+1) z^{2 t+1}}\right) \\
& <\frac{1}{z}-\frac{1}{2 z^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 z^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(since $z \geq 1$ )
Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(z) & >\frac{1}{\left(z^{2}+z\right)\left(\frac{1}{z}-\frac{1}{3 z^{2}}+\frac{1}{3 z^{3}}\right)^{2}}-1 \\
& =\frac{36 z^{5}}{(z+1)\left(6 z^{2}-3 z+2\right)^{2}}-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Expanding the denominator of the above fraction gives

$$
(z+1)\left(6 z^{2}-3 z+2\right)^{2}=36 z^{5}-3 z^{3}+21 z^{2}-8 z+4
$$

It can be shown that the cubic equation $-3 x^{3}+21 x^{2}-8 x+4=0$ has exactly one real root at $x \approx 6.62802$. Moreover, for all $x>6.62802$, we have $-3 x^{3}+21 x^{2}-8 x+4<0$, and hence $(x+1)\left(6 x^{2}-3 x+2\right)^{2}<$ $36 x^{5}$. Since $z \geq 7$, it follows that

$$
f^{\prime}(z)>\frac{36 z^{3}}{(z+1)\left(6 z^{2}-3 z+2\right)^{2}}-1>\frac{36 z^{5}}{36 z^{3}}-1>0
$$

Now, since $f$ is differentiable on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$, we have shown that (2) holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ with $7 \leq x<y$. For the remaining cases, one can verify that $f(1)<f(2)<\cdots<f(7)$. Hence, (2) holds for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ with $x<y$.

The limits in the following three lemmas (A.2-A.4) are taken over only integers (as opposed to real numbers).

Lemma A. 2 (Euler [10], Mascheroni [16]). Let $\gamma \approx 0.57721$ be the Euler-Mascheroni constant. Then, $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{0}(x)-\log x\right)=\gamma$.

Lemma A.3. For any $c \geq-1, \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{c}(x)-\log (x+c+1)\right)$ exists and is finite.

Proof. We first consider the case $c=-1$. Observe that $h_{-1}(x)=$ $h_{0}(x-1)$ for any integer $x>0$. Furthermore, we have

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}(\log x-\log (x-1))=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \log \left(\frac{x}{x-1}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \log \left(1+\frac{1}{x-1}\right) \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{-1}(x)-\log x\right) & =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{-1}(x)-\log (x-1)\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{0}(x-1)-\log (x-1)\right) \\
& =\gamma
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\gamma$ is the Euler-Mascheroni constant, thus proving the result for $c=-1$.

For $c>-1$, we have, for any integer $x>2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{c}(x) & =\sum_{k=1}^{x} \frac{1}{k+c} \\
& =\int_{k=1}^{x} \int_{k}^{k+1} \frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{1}^{x+1} \frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log (x+c+1) & =\int_{1}^{x+c+1} \frac{1}{s} \mathrm{~d} s \\
& =\int_{1-c}^{x+1} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t \quad \text { (by substituting } s=t+c \text { ) } \\
& =\int_{1}^{x+1} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t+\int_{1-c}^{1} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{c}(x)-\log (x+c+1) \\
& =\int_{1}^{x+1}\left(\frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}}-\frac{1}{t+c}\right) \mathrm{d} t-\int_{1-c}^{1} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{2}^{x+1}\left(\frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}}-\frac{1}{t+c}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{~d} t-\int_{1-c}^{2} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{c}(x)-\log (x+c+1)\right) \\
& =\int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}}-\frac{1}{t+c}\right) \mathrm{d} t+D_{1}(c)-D_{2}(c)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $D_{1}(c)=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}} \mathrm{d} t$ and $D_{2}(c)=\int_{1-c}^{2} \frac{1}{t+c} \mathrm{~d} t$ are finite. Therefore, it suffices to prove that $\int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}}-\frac{1}{t+c}\right) \mathrm{d} t$ is finite. When $c=0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]}-\frac{1}{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+D_{1}(0)-D_{2}(0) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{0}(x)-\log (x+1)\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{-1}(x+1)-\log (x+1)\right) \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{-1}(y)-\log y\right) \\
& =\gamma
\end{aligned}
$$

as shown in the case $c=-1$; hence, $\int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]}-\frac{1}{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t$ is finite. Now, for $t \geq 2$, we have $\lfloor t\rfloor+c>\lfloor t\rfloor / 2$ and $t+c>t / 2$, and so,

$$
\frac{1}{\lfloor t\rfloor+c}-\frac{1}{t+c}=\frac{t-\lfloor t\rfloor}{\left(\lfloor t\rfloor+c\right)(t+c)} \leq \frac{t-\lfloor t\rfloor}{\frac{\lfloor t\rfloor}{2}-\frac{t}{2}}=4\left(\frac{1}{\lfloor t\rfloor}-\frac{1}{t}\right)
$$

Since $\int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]}-\frac{1}{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t$ is finite, we get that $\int_{2}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{[t]+\mathrm{c}}-\frac{1}{t+c}\right) \mathrm{d} t$ is finite by the comparison test for integrals. This shows that $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{c}(x)-\right.$ $\log (x+c+1))$ exists for $c>-1$.

Using Lemma A.3, we can now prove the following result.
Lemma A.4. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $c \geq-1$. Then,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{h_{c}, k}(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{\lambda_{c+1}, k}(x)=\log \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)
$$

Proof. For the right equality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{\lambda_{c+1}, k}(x) & =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\lambda_{c+1}((k+1) x)-\lambda_{c+1}(k x)\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}(\log ((k+1) x+c+1)-\log (k x+c+1)) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \log \frac{(k+1) x+c+1}{k x+c+1} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \log \frac{k+1+\frac{c+1}{x}}{k+\frac{c+1}{x}} \\
& =\log \frac{k+1}{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the left equality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} & \left(\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(x)-\Delta_{\lambda_{c+1}, k}(x)\right) \\
= & \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\left(h_{c}((k+1) x)-h_{c}(k x)\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad-\left(\lambda_{c+1}((k+1) x)-\lambda_{c+1}(k x)\right)\right) \\
= & \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{c}((k+1) x)-\lambda_{c+1}((k+1) x)\right) \\
& \quad-\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(h_{c}(k x)-\lambda_{c+1}(k x)\right) \\
= & 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last transition follows from Lemma A.3.
Lemma A.5. Let $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}>0$ with $a \leq b$. Then,

$$
\sum_{k=a}^{b} \frac{1}{k}<\int_{a-1 / 2}^{b+1 / 2} \frac{1}{x} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

Proof. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{a-\frac{1}{2}}^{b+\frac{1}{2}} \frac{1}{x} \mathrm{~d} x-\sum_{k=a}^{b} \frac{1}{k} \\
& =\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k+\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x+\int_{k}^{k+\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x-\int_{k}^{k-\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2 k-x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& \text { (by the substitution } x \leftarrow 2 k-x \text { ) }
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x+\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{2 k-x}-\frac{1}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& =\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{2 k-x}-\frac{2}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& >\sum_{k=a}^{b}\left(\int_{k-\frac{1}{2}}^{k}\left(\frac{4}{2 k}-\frac{2}{k}\right) \mathrm{d} x\right) \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the inequality follows from the inequality of arithmetic and harmonic means, and this inequality is strict for a positive interval of $x$.

Lemma A.6. Let $c \geq 0$, and let $a, b, k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $a<b$. Then, $\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(a)<\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(b)$.

Proof. Note that

$$
\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(b)=h_{c}((k+1) b)-h_{c}(k b)=\sum_{i=1}^{b} \frac{1}{k b+i+c}
$$

and

$$
\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(a)=h_{c}((k+1) a)-h_{c}(k a)=\sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{k a+i+c}
$$

Since the two sums have different numbers of terms, we cannot compare each term in the sum in (3) with the corresponding term in the sum in (4). Instead, we approximate the sum in (4) using an integral. By Lemma A.5,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{k a+i+c}<\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{\frac{1}{2}+a} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

We can now write this integral as a sum of $b$ terms, by dividing the interval into $b$ equal parts:

$$
\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{\frac{1}{2}+a} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x=\sum_{i=1}^{b}\left(\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x\right)
$$

Now each of the sums in (3) and (6) has exactly $b$ terms, and we can compare each term with the corresponding term in the other sum. We show that for each $i \in\{1, \ldots, b\}$,

$$
\frac{1}{k b+i+c} \geq \int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

To compare the two terms in (7), we first write the left-hand side as an integral with the same interval as the right-hand side:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{k b+i+c} & =\frac{a}{b} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+\frac{c a}{b}} \\
& =\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+\frac{c a}{b}} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& \geq \int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+c} \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality follows from the fact that $c a / b \leq c$ as $a<b$ and $c \geq 0$. Hence, it suffices to show that

$$
\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b} \frac{1}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+c} \mathrm{~d} x \geq \int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i-1 \mid a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1 a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

which by substituting $x=\frac{i a}{b}+y$ is equivalent to

$$
\int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+c} \mathrm{~d} y \geq \int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+y+c} \mathrm{~d} y
$$

Let $t=k a+i a / b+c$. Then, the above inequality is equivalent to

$$
\int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y \geq 0
$$

Note that if $a / b \leq 1 / 2$, then $1 / 2-a / b \geq 0$. In this case, for all $y$ in the interval, we have $y \geq 0$ and so $1 / t \geq 1 /(t+y)$. Subsequently, the integrand in (9) is never negative, and is positive when $y=1 / 2$. As a result, inequality (9) holds.

It remains to prove that (9) holds when $a / b>1 / 2$, that is, $1 / 2-$ $a / b<0$. We first divide the integral in (9) into two parts, noting that $1 / t-1 /(t+y)>0$ if and only if $y>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{0}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

We then rewrite the second integral on the right-hand side such that it has the same interval as the first integral, using a series of variable substitutions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{0}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y & =-\int_{\frac{a}{b}-\frac{1}{2}}^{0}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-x}\right) \mathrm{d} x \\
& \text { (by substituting } y=-x \text { ) } \\
& =\int_{0}^{\frac{a}{b}-\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-x}\right) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{2 a}{b}-1\right)\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-\left(\frac{2 a}{b}-1\right) x}\right) \mathrm{d} z . \\
& \text { (by substituting } x=\left(\frac{2 a}{b}-1\right) z \text { ) }
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting back into (10) and replacing the variable $z$ with $y$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{b}}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
& \quad=\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}\right)+\left(\frac{2 a}{b}-1\right)\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-\left(\frac{2 a}{b}-1\right) y}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we use algebraic manipulation to show that the integrand is non-negative for all $y$ in the interval. Writing $q=\frac{2 y}{b}-1$, the integrand becomes

$$
\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+y}+q\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-q y}\right)=\frac{y}{t(t+y)}-\frac{q^{2} y}{t(t-q y)}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{y\left(t-q y-q^{2} t-q^{2} y\right)}{t(t+y)(t-q y)} \\
& =\frac{y\left(t\left(1-q^{2}\right)-q y(1+q)\right)}{t(t+y)(t-q y)} \\
& =\frac{y(t(1-q)(1+q)-q y(1+q))}{t(t+y)(t-q y)} \\
& =\frac{y(1+q)(t(1-q)-q y)}{t(t+y)(t-q y)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We now show that the expression in the last line is non-negative for all $y \in[0,1 / 2]$, by showing that all the factors in the numerator are non-negative and all the factors in the denominator are positive. Clearly, $y \geq 0$ and $1+q=2 a / b \geq 0$. Moreover, since $t=k a+i a / b+c$, we have $t+y \geq t>0$. Hence, it remains to prove that $t(1-q)-q y \geq 0$ and $t-q y>0$.

To show that $t(1-q)-q y \geq 0$ for all $y \in[0,1 / 2]$, it suffices to show that $t \geq q /(2-2 q) \geq q y /(1-q)$. Note that $1-q=2-2 a / b>0$ as we assume that $a<b$. By algebraic manipulation, we can see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{q}{2-2 q} & =\frac{\frac{2 a}{b}-1}{4-\frac{4 a}{b}} \\
& =\frac{2 a-b}{4 b-4 a} \\
& =\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{a}{b-a}-1\right) \\
& <a \\
& <t .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, we have $t(1-q)-q y \geq 0$ for all $y \in[0,1 / 2]$. Furthermore, by the assumption that $a / b>1 / 2$, we have $q=2 a / b-1>0$, and so $1-q<1$. Then, $t-q y>t(1-q)-q y \geq 0$. As a result, the expression in (11) is non-negative for all $y \in[0,1 / 2]$. It follows that the inequality (9) also holds for the case where $a / b>1 / 2$.

Putting everything together, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{h_{c}, k}(b)-\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(a) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{b} \frac{1}{k b+i+c}-\sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{k a+i+c} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{b} \frac{1}{k b+i+c}-\sum_{i=1}^{b}\left(\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i(-1) a}{b}}^{2+\frac{a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x\right) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{b}\left(\frac{1}{k b+i+c}-\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i(-1) a}{b}}^{2+\frac{a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x\right) \\
& \geq \sum_{i=1}^{b}\left(\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i(-1) a}{b}}^{2+\frac{a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+\frac{i a}{b}+c} \mathrm{~d} x-\int_{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i(-1) a}{b}}^{2+\frac{a}{b}} \frac{1}{k a+x+c} \mathrm{~d} x\right) \\
& \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the desired inequality.
We are now ready to prove Proposition 4.6.
Proposition 4.6. The function $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3b if and only if $-1 \leq c \leq 1 / \log 2-1(\approx 0.443)$.

Proof. ( $\Leftarrow$ ) We show that $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3b for $-1 \leq$ $c \leq 1 / \log 2-1$. We first show this for $-1 \leq c<0$. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Consider the left inequality of Condition 3b. If $c=-1$ and $k=0$, then $\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)=\infty>\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(a)$, so the left inequality holds. Otherwise, $k+1+c>0$. Then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(a) & =h_{c}((k+2) a)-h_{c}((k+1) a) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{(k+1) a+t+c} \\
& \leq \sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{(k+1) a+1+c} \\
& =\frac{a}{(k+1) a+1+c} \\
& =\frac{1}{(k+1)+(1+c) / a} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{k+1} \\
& <\frac{1}{(k+1)+c} \\
& =\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

proving the left inequality of Condition 3b. Now, consider the right inequality of Condition 3b. By a similar approach, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(a) & =h_{c}((k+2) a)-h_{c}((k+1) a) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{(k+1) a+t+c} \\
& \geq \sum_{i=1}^{a} \frac{1}{(k+1) a+a+c} \\
& =\frac{a}{(k+2) a+c} \\
& =\frac{1}{(k+2)+c / a} \\
& >\frac{1}{k+2} \\
& \geq \frac{1}{(k+2)+1+c} \\
& =\Delta_{h_{c}, k+2}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

proving the right inequality of Condition 3b.
Next, we show that $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 3b for $0 \leq c \leq 1 / \log 2-$ 1. Let $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. Consider the left inequality of Condition 3b. By Lemma A.1, we have

$$
c \leq \frac{1}{\log 2}-1 \leq \frac{1}{\log \left(\frac{k+2}{k+1}\right)}-(k+1)
$$

and therefore,

$$
\Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)=h_{c}(k+1)-h_{c}(k)=\frac{1}{k+1+c} \geq \log \left(\frac{k+2}{k+1}\right)
$$

On the other hand, from Lemma A.4, we have

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(x)=\log \left(\frac{k+2}{k+1}\right)
$$

By Lemma A.6, $\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}$ is strictly increasing on the domain of positive integers. So, we have

$$
\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(a)<\log \left(\frac{k+2}{k+1}\right) \leq \Delta_{h_{c}, k}(1)
$$

for all $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, proving the left inequality of Condition 3b. Now, consider the right inequality of Condition 3b. By Lemma A.6, $\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}$ is increasing on the domain of positive integers. It follows that

$$
\Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(a) \geq \Delta_{h_{c}, k+1}(1)=\frac{1}{k+2+c}>\frac{1}{k+3+c}=\Delta_{h_{c}, k+2}(1)
$$

for all $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, proving the right inequality of Condition 3b.
$(\Rightarrow)$ We show that $h_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 3b for $c>$ $1 / \log 2-1$. To this end, we prove that $\Delta_{h_{c}, 0}(1) \leq \Delta_{h_{c}, 1}(a)$ for some $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. The expression on the left-hand side of the inequality is $\Delta_{h_{c}, 0}(1)=h_{c}(1)-h_{c}(0)=1 /(1+c)<\log 2$ since $c>1 / \log 2-1$. For the expression on the right-hand side of the inequality, by Lemma A.4, we have $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \Delta_{h_{c}, 1}(x)=\log 2$. Since $\Delta_{h_{c}, 0}(1)<\log 2$, by definition of limit, there exists $a \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $\Delta_{h_{c}, 1}(a) \geq \Delta_{h_{c}, 0}(1)$. Hence, $h_{c}$ does not satisfy Condition 3 b.

and so

Proposition 4.13. The function $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5 if and only if $-1 \leq c \leq 1 / \log 2-1(=0.443)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{c}((t+1) b+r a)-h_{c}(t b+r a) \\
& \quad=\sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{h_{c}, t b+r a+t}(1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) }
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \geq \sum_{t=0}^{b-1} \Delta_{h_{c},(k+1) b-1+t}(1) \\
& \text { (by Condition 3a and }(k+1) b-1 \geq t b+r a) \\
& =h_{c}((k+2) b-1)-h_{c}((k+1) b-1) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\

& =h_{c}((k+2) a)-h_{c}((k+1) a) \\

(by Condition 3a)
so $h_{c}$ satisfies Condition 5.

## B WELFARE FUNCTION MUST BE STRICTLY INCREASING TO GUARANTEE EF1

In this section, we justify why we require the function defining the additive welfarist rules to be strictly increasing.

Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a function continuous on $\mathbb{R}_{>0}$. Suppose that $f$ is non-decreasing but not strictly increasing. We show that there exists a simple instance such that the additive welfarist rule with $f$ does not always choose an EF1 allocation.

Since $f$ is not strictly increasing, there exist $a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ with $a<b$ such that for all $x \in(a, b)$, we have $f(a)=f(x)=f(b)$. Let $d$ be a positive integer larger than $3 /(b-a)$. We claim that there exists $c \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that $(c-1) / d, c / d,(c+1) / d \in(a, b)$. Let $W=\{w \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}: w / d>a\}$. Since $\lceil a d+1\rceil \in W, W$ is nonempty. Let $c^{\prime}$ be the smallest element in $W$. We show that $c=c^{\prime}+1$ satisfies the claim. Since $c^{\prime}-1 \notin W$, we have $\left(c^{\prime}-1\right) / d \leq a$. Then, $\left(c^{\prime}+\right.$ $2) / d=\left(c^{\prime}-1\right) / d+3 / d<a+(b-a)=b$. This implies that $a<c^{\prime} / d<\left(c^{\prime}+1\right) / d<\left(c^{\prime}+2\right) / d<b$, proving the claim.

Now, consider an instance with $n \geq 2$ agents and $m=n c$ goods such that $u_{i}(g)=1 / d$ for all $i \in N, g \in M$. This instance is positive-admitting, identical-good, and normalized. The only EF1 allocation $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right)$ gives $c$ goods to each agent, thereby achieving $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=n f(c / d)$. Consider another allocation $\mathcal{B}=\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right)$ where agent 1 receives $c+1$ goods, agent 2 receives $c-1$ goods, and every other agent receives $c$ goods; this allocation is not EF1. We have $\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(B_{i}\right)\right)=f((c+1) / d)+$ $f((c-1) / d)+(n-2) f(c / d)=n f(c / d)=\sum_{i \in N} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$. This means that if the additive welfarist rule with $f$ can choose an EF1 allocation (i.e., $\mathcal{A}$ ), it can also choose $\mathcal{B}$, which is not EF1. Hence, this additive welfarist rule cannot always guarantee EF1.

## C VALUES OF THE MODIFIED HARMONIC NUMBER ON INTEGERS

Let $c>-1$ and $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{c}(x) & =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{x+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{1}\left(\left(t^{c}-t^{x+c}\right) \sum_{r=0}^{\infty} t^{r}\right) \mathrm{d} t \quad \text { (expansion of }(1-t)^{-1} \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \sum_{r=0}^{\infty}\left(t^{r+c}-t^{r+c+x}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\sum_{r=0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{1}\left(t^{r+c}-t^{r+c+x}\right) \mathrm{d} t \quad\left(\text { since } t^{r+c}-t^{r+c+x} \geq 0\right) \\
& =\sum_{r=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{r+1+c}-\frac{1}{r+1+c+x}\right) \quad(r+c, r+c+x \neq-1) \\
& =\sum_{r=1}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{r+c}-\frac{1}{r+c+x}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

When $x=0$, this sum is equal to 0 , and hence $h_{c}(0)=0$. Otherwise, $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{c}(x) & =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{r=1}^{x}\left(\frac{1}{r+c}-\frac{1}{r+c+x}\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}-\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c+x}\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}+\sum_{r=x+1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}\right. \\
& \left.\sum_{r=1}^{x-x} \frac{1}{r+c+x}-\sum_{r=x+1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c+x}\right) \\
& =\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}-\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{r=x-x+1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c+x} \\
& =\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}-\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{x+c+r} \\
& =\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}-\sum_{r=1}^{x} \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{x+c+r} \\
& =\sum_{r=1}^{x} \frac{1}{r+c}
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that

$$
h_{c}(x)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{1+c}+\frac{1}{2+c}+\cdots+\frac{1}{x+c} & \text { if } x \geq 1 \\ 0 & \text { if } x=0\end{cases}
$$

holds for $c>-1$.
Now, we consider the case $c=-1$. We have

$$
h_{-1}(0)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1-t^{-1}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t=\int_{0}^{1}-\frac{1}{t} \mathrm{~d} t=-\infty
$$

and for $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, we have

$$
h_{-1}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1-t^{x-1}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{0}-t^{(x-1)+0}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t=h_{0}(x-1)
$$

This shows that

$$
h_{-1}(x)= \begin{cases}1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{x-1} & \text { if } x \geq 2 \\ 0 & \text { if } x=1 \\ -\infty & \text { if } x=0\end{cases}
$$

holds.

## D OTHER PROPERTIES OF ADDITIVE WELFARIST RULES
## D. 1 Normalized Instances with Two Agents

We continue the discussion from Section 3.3.
Recall the definition of $\varphi_{p}$ from Section 2.1. Eckart et al. [9] proved that for $p \leq 0$, the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p}$ guarantees EF1 for the class of normalized instances with two agents. We shall show that there exist other additive welfarist rules that also ensure EF1 for this class of instances.

We rewrite Lemma 3 of Eckart et al. [9] as follows.
Proposition D. 1 (Eckart et al. [9, Lemma 3]). $\varphi_{p}$ satisfies Condition 2 for all $p \leq 0$.

Note that Eckart et al. [9, Lemma 3] used a restricted version of Condition 2 where $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ instead of $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, but this can be easily extended to our version of Condition 2. Indeed, if at least one of $a, b, c, d$ is zero, then $\min \{a, b\} \leq \min \{c, d\}$ and $a b<c d$ implies that at least one of $a$ and $b$ is zero while $c$ and $d$ are both positive. Hence, for $p \leq 0$ we have $\varphi_{p}(a)+\varphi_{p}(b)=-\infty<\varphi_{p}(c)+\varphi_{p}(d)$, and so $\varphi_{p}$ satisfies Condition 2.

We show that any linear combination of such $\varphi_{p}$ also satisfies Condition 2. More formally, let $\Psi$ be the set of all functions $\psi$ : $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ for which there exist $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}, a_{1}, \ldots, a_{k} \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, and $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{k} \leq 0$ such that $\psi=\sum_{j=1}^{k} a_{i} \varphi_{p_{i}}$. Then, the following proposition follows directly from Proposition D.1.

Proposition D.2. Let $\psi \in \Psi$. Then, $\psi$ satisfies Condition 2.
In the following proposition, we show that beyond the $p$-mean rules, there exist other additive welfarist rules that guarantee EF1 for the class of normalized instances with two agents. Note that the function $\psi$ in the proposition statement satisfies $\psi \in \Psi$, so the additive welfarist rule with $\psi$ guarantees EF1 for this class of instances by Propositions 3.18 and D.2.

Proposition D.3. Let $\psi=\varphi_{0}+40 \varphi_{-1}$. Then, the additive welfarist rule with $\psi$ is not equivalent to the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p}$ for any $p \leq 0$.

Proof. For each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, define the instance $I_{k}$ with two agents and $m=2 k+1$ goods such that the utilities of the goods are as follows.

- $u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)=4$ for $j \in\{1, \ldots, k\}, u_{1}\left(g_{k+1}\right)=1$, and $u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)=0$ for $j \in\{k+2, \ldots, m\}$.
- $u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)=2$ for $j \in\{1, \ldots, 2 k\}$, and $u_{2}\left(g_{m}\right)=1$.

This instance is a normalized instance; moreover, it is positiveadmitting since the allocation where agent 1 receives $g_{1}$ and agent 2 receives the remaining goods gives positive utility to every agent.

Let $f$ be a function that satisfies Condition 2, and let $\mathcal{A}=\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ be an allocation chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. We
have $\left\{g_{k+2}, \ldots, g_{m}\right\} \subseteq A_{2}$; otherwise, if some of these goods are with agent 1 , then transferring these goods to agent 2 increases $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)$ and does not decrease $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)$, thereby increasing $\sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. By Proposition 3.18, $\mathcal{A}$ is EF1. We have $\left|A_{1}\right| \geq k / 2$; otherwise, if $\left|A_{1}\right|<k / 2$, then we have $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)<$ $4(k / 2)=2 k$ and $u_{1}\left(A_{2} \backslash\{g\}\right)>4(k / 2)=2 k$ for all $g \in A_{2}$, making the allocation not EF1. Moreover, we have $\left|A_{1}\right| \leq k$; otherwise, if $\left|A_{1}\right|>k$, then $A_{1}=\left\{g_{1}, \ldots, g_{k+1}\right\}$ and $A_{2}=\left\{g_{k+2}, \ldots, g_{m}\right\}$, and we have $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)=2 k-1<2 k=u_{2}\left(A_{1} \backslash\{g\}\right)$, making the allocation not EF1. Finally, we have $g_{k+1} \in A_{2}$; otherwise, exchanging $g_{k+1} \in A_{1}$ with $g \in A_{2}$ for any $g \in\left\{g_{1}, \ldots, g_{k}\right\}$ increases $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)$ and does not decrease $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)$, thereby increasing $\sum_{i=1}^{2} f\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)$ and contradicting the assumption that $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with $f$. Overall, we have agent 1 receiving $x$ goods from $\left\{g_{1}, \ldots, g_{k}\right\}$ for some $k / 2 \leq x \leq k$ and agent 2 receiving the remaining goods. This gives $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)=4 x$ and $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)=2(2 k-x)+1=4 k+1-2 x$.

Note that $\varphi_{p}$ and $\psi$ both satisfy Condition 2 by Propositions D. 1 and D.2.

For $p=0$, it can be verified (e.g., by exhaustion) that in the instance $I_{20}$, we have $x=20$ for $\varphi_{0}$ and $x=18$ for $\psi$, so the additive welfarist rules defined by the two respective functions are different.

Consider the case $p<0$. For each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, let $F_{k}(y)=-(4 y)^{p}-$ $(4 k+1-2 y)^{p}$. We have $\sum_{i=1}^{2} \varphi_{p}\left(u_{i}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=F_{k}(x)$. Then,

$$
x=\underset{y \in[k / 2, k] \cap \mathbb{Z}}{\arg \max } F_{k}(y)
$$

Note that

$$
\frac{\partial F_{k}}{\partial y}=2 p\left((4 k+1-2 y)^{p-1}-2(4 y)^{p-1}\right)
$$

and

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} F_{k}}{\partial y^{2}}=-4 p(p-1)\left((4 k+1-2 y)^{p-2}+4(4 y)^{p-2}\right)<0
$$

so $F_{k}(y)$ (when viewed as a real function) achieves the maximum at $\partial F_{k} / \partial y=0$. Let $y^{*}$ be the value of $y$ at $\partial F_{k} / \partial y=0$. Then, we have $y^{*}=(4 k+1) /\left(2+2^{(2 p-1) /(p-1)}\right)$, and $x=\left\lfloor y^{*}\right\rfloor$ or $x=\left\lceil y^{*}\right\rceil$.

Suppose that the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p}$ chooses the same allocation as that with $\psi$ in $I_{20}$, i.e., $x=18$. Then, we have $y^{*}<19$, and with $k=20$ it follows that $1 /\left(2+2^{(2 p-1) /(p-1)}\right)<$ $19 / 81$. Now, consider the instance $I_{100}$. We have $y^{*}=(4 k+1) /(2+$ $\left.2^{(2 p-1) /(p-1)}\right)<401(19 / 81)<95$, so the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p}$ chooses an allocation that gives fewer than 96 goods to agent 1 . On the other hand, it can be verified that the additive welfarist rule with $\psi$ chooses an allocation that gives 96 goods to agent 1. Therefore, the two additive welfarist rules are not equivalent.

By a similar argument, it can be shown that for any $p_{4}<p_{3} \leq$ $p_{2}<p_{1} \leq 0$, there exists $a \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that the additive welfarist rule with $\psi=\varphi_{p_{1}}+a \varphi_{p_{2}}$ is not a $p$-mean rule for any $p \leq 0$, and there exists $b \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p_{1}}+$ $b \varphi_{p_{2}}$ is different from the additive welfarist rule with $\varphi_{p_{3}}+b \varphi_{p_{4}}$.

We now show that the additive welfarist rules defined by the modified logarithmic functions $\lambda_{c}$ and modified harmonic functions $h_{c}$ do not guarantee EF1 for normalized instances with two agents.

Proposition D.4. For each $c>0$, there exists a positive-admitting normalized instance with two agents such that the additive welfarist rule with $\lambda_{c}$ does not choose an EF1 allocation.

Proof. Let $c>0$. Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that the additive welfarist rule with function $\lambda_{c}$ guarantees EF1 for all positive-admitting normalized instances with two agents.

Define the instance $\mathcal{I}_{z}$ for any $z \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ to be the normalized instance with 2 agents, 9 goods, and the following utilities:

- $u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)=3 z$ for $j \leq 8$ and $u_{1}\left(g_{9}\right)=z$;
- $u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)=5 z$ for $j \leq 5$ and $u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)=0$ for $j \geq 6$.

Take an arbitrary $z \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ and consider the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $\lambda_{c}$. We must have $\left\{g_{6}, \ldots, g_{9}\right\} \subseteq A_{1}$; otherwise, the welfare can be increased by moving any of $g_{6}, \ldots, g_{9}$ to $A_{1}$. Furthermore, by our assumption, this allocation must be EF1. Hence, we must have $\left\{g_{6}, \ldots, g_{9}\right\} \subseteq$ $A_{1}$; otherwise, agent 1 is not EF1 towards agent 2 . Then, $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \geq$ $13 z$ and $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right) \leq 20 z$.

Fix some good $g_{j} \in A_{1}$ with $j \leq 5$. Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)\right)-\lambda_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)\right) \\
& =\log \left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)+c\right)-\log \left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)+c\right) \\
& =\log \left(\frac{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)+c}{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}\right) \\
& \leq \log \left(\frac{13 z+c}{10 z+c}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lambda_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)\right)-\lambda_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad=\log \left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)+c\right)-\log \left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+c\right) \\
& \quad=\log \left(\frac{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+c}\right) \\
& \quad \geq \log \left(\frac{25 z+c}{20 z+c}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{z \rightarrow 0^{+}} & \left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} z}\left(\log \left(\frac{13 z+c}{10 z+c}\right)-\log \left(\frac{25 z+c}{20 z+c}\right)\right)\right) \\
& =\lim _{z \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\left(\frac{13}{13 z+c}-\frac{10}{10 z+c}\right)-\left(\frac{25}{25 z+c}-\frac{20}{20 z+c}\right)\right) \\
& =\frac{3}{c}-\frac{5}{c} \\
& <0
\end{aligned}
$$

When $z=0$ we have

$$
\log \left(\frac{13 z+c}{10 z+c}\right)=\log \left(\frac{25 z+c}{20 z+c}\right)=\log \left(\frac{c}{c}\right)=0
$$

so for small enough $z>0$,

$$
\log \left(\frac{13 z+c}{10 z+c}\right)<\log \left(\frac{25 z+c}{20 z+c}\right)
$$

Fix such a small enough $z$, and consider the instance $\mathcal{I}_{z}$ and the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $\lambda_{c}$. Combining (21), (22), and (23), we get for this $z$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lambda_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)\right)-\lambda_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)\right) \\
& \quad<\lambda_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)\right)-\lambda_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In other words, moving some $g_{j} \in A_{1}$ with $j \leq 5$ to $A_{2}$ strictly increases the welfare. This contradicts the assumption that the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $\lambda_{c}$.

Proposition D.5. For each $c>-1$, there exists a positive-admitting normalized instance with two agents such that the additive welfarist rule with $h_{c}$ does not choose an EF1 allocation.

Proof. Let $c>-1$. Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that the additive welfarist rule with function $h_{c}$ guarantees EF1 for all positive-admitting normalized instances with two agents. Note that we use the extension of $h_{c}$ to the non-negative real domain, since the agents' utilities can take any non-negative real value.

For an arbitrary $z \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, consider the instance $\mathcal{I}_{z}$ defined in the proof of Proposition D. 4 and the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $h_{c}$. As shown in the proof of Proposition D.4, there exists $g_{j} \in A_{1}$ with $j \leq 5$, and moreover $u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \geq 13 z$ and $u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right) \leq 20 z$.

Fix some good $g_{j} \in A_{1}$ with $j \leq 5$. Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)\right)-h_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)\right) \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \quad-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}-t^{u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \quad \leq \int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{10 z+c}-t^{13 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)\right)-h_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)\right) \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \quad-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{c}-t^{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+c}-t^{u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \quad \geq \int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{20 z+c}-t^{25 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{z \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} z}\left(\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{10 z+c}-t^{13 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{20 z+c}-t^{25 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t\right)\right) \\
& =\lim _{z \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\left(10 t^{10 z+c}-13 t^{13 z+c}-20 t^{20 z+c}+25 t^{25 z+c}\right) \log t}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t\right) \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{2 t^{c} \log t}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

$<0$.
When $z=0$ we have

$$
\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{10 z+c}-t^{13 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{20 z+c}-t^{25 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t=0
$$

so for small enough $z>0$,

$$
\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{10 z+c}-t^{13 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t<\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t^{20 z+c}-t^{25 z+c}}{1-t} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

Fix such a small enough $z$, and consider the instance $J_{z}$ and the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $h_{c}$. Combining (24), (25), and (26), we get for this $z$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& h_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)\right)-h_{c}\left(u_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)-u_{1}\left(g_{j}\right)\right) \\
& \quad<h_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)+u_{2}\left(g_{j}\right)\right)-h_{c}\left(u_{2}\left(A_{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In other words, moving some $g_{j} \in A_{1}$ with $j \leq 5$ to $A_{2}$ strictly increases the welfare. This contradicts the assumption that the allocation $\left(A_{1}, A_{2}\right)$ is chosen by the additive welfarist rule with function $h_{c}$.

## D. 2 Integer-Valued Identical-Good Instances

We continue the discussion from Section 4.1.
We state an interesting result regarding functions $f$ satisfying Condition 3: the marginal increase $f(x+1)-f(x)$ grows as $\Theta(1 / x)$ on the positive integers, which means that the function is similar to the logarithmic function in terms of growth rate.

Proposition D.6. Let $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty\}$ be a strictly increasing function that satisfies Condition 3. Then, there exist $C_{1}, C_{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, we have $C_{1} / x \leq f(x+1)-f(x) \leq C_{2} / x$.

Proof. We first prove the left inequality. For all $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, we have $\Delta_{f, x}(1) \geq \Delta_{f, x+1}(1)$ for all $i \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ by Condition 3a. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x+1)-f(x) & =\Delta_{f, x}(1) \\
& \geq \frac{1}{x} \sum_{i=0}^{x-1} \Delta_{f, x+i}(1) \\
& =\frac{1}{x} \sum_{i=0}^{x-1}(f(x+i+1)-f(x+i)) \\
& =\frac{1}{x}(f(2 x)-f(x)) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =\frac{1}{x} \Delta_{f, 1}(x) \\
& >\frac{1}{x} \Delta_{f, 2}(1) \\
& =\frac{f(3)-f(2)}{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting that $C_{1}:=f(3)-f(2) \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ since $f$ is strictly increasing, this establishes the left inequality.

We now turn to the right inequality. Let $x \geq 3$ be a positive integer, and let $y=\lfloor(x+1) / 3\rfloor$. Note that $y \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ and $3 y-1 \leq$ $x$, so $\Delta_{f, 3 y-1}(1) \geq \Delta_{f, x}(1)$ by Condition 3a. Moreover, we have $\Delta_{f, 3 y-1}(1) \leq \Delta_{f, 2 y+i}(1)$ for all $0 \leq i \leq y-1$ by Condition 3a. Therefore,

$$
f(x+1)-f(x)=\Delta_{f, x}(1)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq \Delta_{f, 3 y-1}(1) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{y} \sum_{i=0}^{y-1} \Delta_{f, 2 y+i}(1) \\
& =\frac{1}{y} \sum_{i=0}^{y-1}(f(2 y+i+1)-f(2 y+i)) \\
& =\frac{1}{y}(f(3 y)-f(2 y)) \quad \text { (by telescoping sum) } \\
& =\frac{1}{y} \Delta_{f, 2}(y) \\
& <\frac{1}{y} \Delta_{f, 1}(1) \\
& =\frac{f(2)-f(1)}{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, for $x \geq 3$, we have

$$
y=\left\lfloor\frac{x+1}{3}\right\rfloor \geq \frac{x+1}{3}-1=\frac{x}{3}-\frac{2}{3} \geq \frac{x}{3}-\frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{x}{3}=\frac{x}{9}
$$

and hence

$$
f(x+1)-f(x)<\frac{f(2)-f(1)}{y} \leq \frac{9(f(2)-f(1))}{x}
$$

This shows that $f(x+1)-f(x) \leq C_{2} / x$ for all integers $x \geq 3$, where $C_{2}:=9(f(2)-f(1))$ is positive since $f$ is strictly increasing.

Note that $f(x+1)-f(x) \leq C_{2} / x$ holds trivially for $x=1$. For $x=2$, we have $f(3)-f(2)=\Delta_{f, 2}(1)<\Delta_{f, 1}(1)=f(2)-f(1)=$ $(2 / 9)\left(C_{2} / 2\right) \leq C_{2} / 2$, and so the inequality $f(x+1)-f(x) \leq C_{2} / x$ holds as well.

Next, we show that within the class of $p$-mean rules, the only rule that guarantees EF1 for integer-valued identical-good instances is the 0 -mean rule (i.e., MNW).

Proposition D.7. $p=0$ if and only iffor every positive-admitting integer-valued identical-good instance with $n$ agents, every allocation chosen by the $p$-mean rule is EF1.

Proof. ( $\Leftarrow$ ) First, we show that $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 3 for $p \geq 1$. Since $2^{p} \geq 2$, we have $\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 0}(1)=\varphi_{p}(1)-\varphi_{p}(0)=1 \leq$ $2^{p}-1=\varphi_{p}(2)-\varphi_{p}(1)=\Delta_{\varphi_{p}, 1}(1)$, so Condition 3 is violated.

Next, we show that $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 3 for $0<p<1$. For any $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x\left(\varphi_{p}(x+1)-\varphi_{p}(x)\right) & =x \int_{x}^{x+1} \varphi_{p}^{\prime}(t) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =x \int_{x}^{x+1} p t^{p-1} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \geq x \int_{x}^{x+1} p(x+1)^{p-1} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \text { (since } p>0 \text { and } p-1<0 \text { ) } \\
& =x p(x+1)^{p-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} x p(x+1)^{p-1}=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} p(x+1)^{p}=\infty$, so there does not exist a constant $C \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that $x\left(\varphi_{p}(x+1)-\right.$ $\left.\varphi_{p}(x)\right) \leq C$ for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. By Proposition D.6, $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 3.

Finally, we show that $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 3 for $p<0$. For any $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x\left(\varphi_{p}(x+1)-\varphi_{p}(x)\right) & =x \int_{x}^{x+1} \varphi_{p}^{\prime}(t) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =x \int_{x}^{x+1}-p t^{p-1} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq x \int_{x}^{x+1}-p x^{p-1} \mathrm{~d} t \quad(\text { since } p, p-1<0) \\
& =-p x^{p}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty}-p x^{p}=0$, so there does not exist a constant $C \in \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ such that $x\left(\varphi_{p}(x+1)-\varphi_{p}(x)\right) \geq C$ for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. By Proposition D.6, $\varphi_{p}$ does not satisfy Condition 3.
$(\Rightarrow)$ This follows from the result of Caragiannis et al. [6].

abstract:
Allocating indivisible goods is a ubiquitous task in fair division. We study
additive welfarist rules, an important class of rules which choose an
allocation that maximizes the sum of some function of the agents' utilities.
Prior work has shown that the maximum Nash welfare (MNW) rule is the unique
additive welfarist rule that guarantees envy-freeness up to one good (EF1). We
strengthen this result by showing that MNW remains the only additive welfarist
rule that ensures EF1 for identical-good instances, two-value instances, as
well as normalized instances with three or more agents. On the other hand, if
the agents' utilities are integers, we demonstrate that several other rules
offer the EF1 guarantee, and provide characterizations of these rules for
various classes of instances.
